The text discusses a proposal to add Polygon's MATIC token as collateral on the Compound platform. The proposal is made by Stable Node, who have experience growing the MakerDAO protocol in various markets. MATIC is the ecosystem token of Polygon Network, a scalability solution for Ethereum with over $6B TVL and 350+ deployed dapps across DeFi, NFT, Gaming, and DAO space. The Matic team has contributed to Ethereum's ecosystem for a long time, and the token is listed on over 30 exchanges globally. It is used for gas fees on the Polygon network, participating in its Proof-of-Stake consensus, and as collateral for DeFi protocols like MakerDAO. The Compound community is asked to consider the application and make a formal vote regarding collateral factor, reserve factor, and borrowing limit.

0x DAO experienced a potential exploit where an attacker could inflate their voting power significantly, allowing them to create proposals or decide vote outcomes. The exploit involved repeatedly using operatedPoolIds in castVote and propose methods. No user funds were at risk as 0x DAO is not connected to the core smart contracts.

To address this issue, the contract code was patched, and the treasury was migrated to a new contract through a governance vote. A malicious actor could have blocked the migration, but Joey Zacharl, a delegate, successfully leveraged the exploit to pass the proposal. The 2M ZRX treasury is now safe in the new contract, and the ZRX Portal has been updated accordingly.

This incident served as a test of 0x DAO's on-chain binding governance system. All functionalities remain unchanged, and 0x Labs awarded $50,000 to samczsun for discovering and reporting the vulnerability.

This event aims to foster a sense of belongingness among ApeCoin holders and promote the growth of the DAO community.

This text discusses the creation of a dedicated forum thread for technical maintenance updates related to BGD's Aave platform. The thread aims to improve community visibility on these updates. Maintenance tasks include infrastructure consistency checks and updates, such as activating new features or deprecating old ones. Only proposals that are purely technical and do not create community division will be included. Examples include updating price feed addresses and oracle changes due to asset off-boarding. The posts for each update will follow the structure of an AIP (Aave Improvement Proposal) description, providing both a high-level overview and technical specifications. The updates will be posted 3 days in advance on the forum before being submitted as an AIP. If the community has concerns about any update, the ARFC + AIP procedure will be followed.

The Optimism Mission Review Team operates under a system where additional reviewers can be added by the affirmative vote of ten reviewers, including all relevant teams. If needed, three extra reviewers can be added through this method, after which a proposal for further reviewers must be put forward by the Lead.

The Grants Council is responsible for originating and processing Mission Proposals, reviewing applications in regular cycles, publishing reports outlining grant finalists, assessing whether recipients have met pre-defined milestones, ensuring transparency of operations, and overseeing general administration of the grants program.

The Council Lead oversees the provision of information about the grants program, coordinates meetings, does not vote on decisions or score proposals, communicates grant decisions at the end of each review period, and exercises decision-making authority in case sub-committees cannot reach consensus on administrative or operational matters.

Reviewers are expected to have subject matter expertise, be accessible to grant applicants, work with proposers to ensure proposed milestones are clear, measurable, and achievable within the specified timeframe, maintain a high participation rate in Council votes and meetings, provide voting rationale for each grant that receives a substantive review, and dedicate sufficient time to accomplish their duties.

Grants Council members are subject to representative removal, re-election if they wish to serve for an additional season, transparency checks, retrospective at the end of Season 6, and a proposed budget and charter voted on by Token House according to the Governance Calendar. The grants council will not promote or endorse projects or their underlying products but acknowledge which grant proposers are most suited based on the parameters applied by the mandate of Season 6 governance.

The approved Charter will be published to GitHub, and any material updates to the Charter will be reflected with a new version number at the top of this document, with the updated version going into effect.
The M-Token team suggests introducing an mBTC/sBTC Metapool for increased Bitcoin liquidity on Ethereum, facilitating asset swaps.

The text discusses a proposal for HOST, an immersive learning platform that allows content creators, educators, and mentors to publish Token Gated courses. To enhance learner engagement and bridge the gap between web2 and web3, they are introducing the Otherside initiative, which enables creators to use Yugalabs Otherside for interactive course creation. Completing a course earns an SBT (Soul Bound Token) certificate of competency. The platform combines web2 with blockchain technology for a more efficient learning environment. It incentivizes high-quality content creation, rewards educators, and makes educational resources accessible to students via its Governance token. SBT metadata updates as students complete additional courses on the platform, creating a digital CV/resume. A kickstart of $50,000 in ApeCoin is proposed for Phase 1, with APE coin serving as a payment gateway. The full proposal can be found at the provided link. The implementation may change to optimize security and usability, and any significant deviations will be disclosed to the community.

The text discusses a simple Asset-Liability Management (ALM) spreadsheet for MakerDAO community, designed to help users understand the impact of onboarding collaterals. The spreadsheet allows users to edit certain cells and provides a dashboard presenting outcomes based on inputs.

Key components include an income statement, Surplus Buffer coverage, conditions to meet, a list of possible collaterals, and indicative Return on Assets (RoA) and Capital at Risk (CaR). The USDC PSM line has a red box indicating more proposals than available capital, requiring decisions from MKR holders.

The Surplus Buffer is highlighted as a limitation without an obvious solution, and there isn't enough capital for all current proposals, with expectations of more soon. Support will be provided to those who need help using the spreadsheet, and it will continue to be developed based on usage.
Curve should consume half of its total capacity.

The text discusses a proposal concerning Venus Tokenomics, specifically the VRT Swap & XVS Vesting architecture. An alternative design called "fixed speed vesting" was proposed earlier, which had a fast vesting schedule but required a daily deposit limit due to concerns about bots consuming the quota. However, this daily limit raised technical and user experience issues. After considering feedback, it's decided that the original swap & vesting design should be deployed instead, as the "fixed speed model" cannot prevent the issue with bots. The proposal can be found on the Venus community forum, and the vote will have three options: FOR (adopting the proposed approach), AGAINST (seeking other options), and ABSTAIN (neutral). This proposal will not cause any on-chain action.

Cliff.eth proposes a fee reduction for UNI holders on Uniswap. Tier 1 (1k-5k UNI) pays 25bps, Tier 2 (5k-25k UNI) pays 20bps, and Tier 3 (25k+ UNI) pays 15bps. He suggests the possibility of adding more tiers or a curve for Amount_UNI vs Fee_BPS. Interested parties are invited to discuss this proposal as it benefits UNI holders by providing discounted trading fees on Uniswap, making them feel more at home when using the protocol.

The Lido Liquid Staking protocol uses a rebasing mechanism for distributing staking rewards and fees. Due to the current lack of trustless balance checking between the Consensus and Execution Layers, an Oracle system is employed. This system consists of offchain daemons operated by independent parties who observe and report validator balances. The Lido protocol currently uses 5 Oracle operators, all of whom are Node Operators.

The text discusses a proposal to increase the number of Oracle operators from 5 to either 9 (5/9 consensus) or 11 (7/11 consensus), with a preference for participants who are not currently Node Operators. This move is aimed at enhancing the protocol's robustness and resilience. The text invites interested parties to join Lido's Oracle set on Ethereum, subject to governance decisions regarding the size of the increase and the selection of new participants.

The text also raises questions about remunerating Oracle operators, particularly third parties not tied to Lido revenues, and suggests potential methods for such remuneration if deemed beneficial. The author is a co-founder of Rated and a member of the Lido DAO. Rated expresses interest in participating in the Lido Oracle set as a third party, subject to terms.

The text discusses a proposal by Rage Trade for an additional use grant from Uniswap. Rage Trade is a new perpetual swap protocol built using Uniswap v3, offering capital-efficient leverage trading, leverage LPing, cross-margin, liquidations, and real-time funding rates. They have developed libraries for these features that utilize Uniswap's BUSL protect code, which requires an additional grant.

Approving this proposal would bring new liquidity to UNI v3 as Rage Trade is built on top of it, not a fork. Rage Trade has also designed an efficient v3 LP strategy known as the 80-20 strategy and plans to spend significant R&D resources on designing more strategies. On-chain perpetuals could enable new Uniswap spot strategies, such as mitigating impermanent loss via delta hedging and opening up new avenues and payoffs not currently possible on the spot market. Rage Trade looks forward to discussing their proposal with the Uniswap community.

The text discusses a proposal to list weETH assets on the Venus Protocol, offering potential benefits such as Liquid Restaking Tokens (LRT) from ether.fi on ETH Mainnet. This integration allows users to stake ETH, earn rewards, and gain additional benefits through restaking on EigenLayer. With a significant TVL ($2.7B) in the ether.fi protocol, adding weETH to Venus can boost asset diversity and liquidity.

The integration enables users to earn ether.fi and EigenLayer points for future incentives, along with lending APY on their holdings. A liquidity mining incentive offered by Ether.fi for weETH suppliers is proposed to kickstart the market on Venus and attract more users. This move positions Venus as a pioneer in capturing the restaking market, catering to the growing demand for LRTs and providing users with a wider range of opportunities.

The proposal aligns with the community's focus on decentralization, sustainability, and supporting the Ethereum ecosystem. It enhances asset diversity and liquidity while strengthening the collaboration between Venus and ether.fi to drive innovation and value creation for users.

The text discusses updates to the Core Pool and Supply/Borrow caps in a decentralized lending platform called Venus. The changes include an increase in collateral factors for XRP, FIL, LTC, and ADA, with minimal impact on risk variables like VaR (95th percentile of protocol losses) and EVaR (Extreme VaR). Simulations suggest a potential borrow increase of $180K without affecting these risk variables. The liquidity analysis indicates sufficient on-chain liquidity for significant liquidations with the updated parameters, and no outsized positions were identified. For TUSD (Core Pool), the supply cap utilization has reached 100%, but doubling it to 3M does not increase system VaR. Similarly, WBETH's borrow cap utilization is at 100%, prompting a recommendation to double it to 2,200. The text also includes links to images showing top borrowers and suppliers, as well as stress test results for TUSD supply and WBETH borrow caps.

This proposal seeks funding for auditing new core contracts and Aragon.app frontend. The requested budget is equivalent to $200,000, which will be held in ESD Multisig until approved by the Tech sub-DAO. The funds are intended for technical audits only and will be used to increase security and trust in Aragon products. The timeline for the audit depends on the completion of the product by Aragon Association teams. The proposal emphasizes the importance of independent audits for high-risk products, but notes that a successful audit doesn't eliminate all potential vulnerabilities. The ESD Multisig, responsible for releasing funds, includes Renee, Daniel, Ivan, Alex, and Rick. The Tech sub-DAO, responsible for appointing auditors, includes Sam, Voronchuk, and Pau. The ESD should not fund from its existing budget or be the entity funding the audit.

Title: Special Council - Role Clarification and Future Election Requirements

   The proposal aims to clarify the role of the Special Council in the APE Foundation as an Advisory Board, with no corporate decision-making power. Key qualities for effective advisory board members include diverse knowledge, familiarity with the ApeCoin DAO ecosystem, good judgment, communication skills, commitment, integrity, and team player abilities.

   Nominees for the Advisory Board must have been discourse members for at least 6 months prior to their term and achieve a minimum of Trust Level 2 on discourse. The primary responsibility of Advisory Council members is to conduct administrative reviews of AIPs.

   Weekly reports established by AIP-305 are being removed as they have shown minimal engagement and are not appropriate for advisory boards.

   Implementing these changes could yield benefits such as clarity, fit, and focus within the ApeCoin DAO, promoting long-term sustainability and efficiency. The changes will be effective for the election cycle of council members commencing January 1, 2025, with immediate revisions to any election communications and processes. No ApeCoin is requested from the treasury for these changes.

The text discusses a proposal by Stakecraft for funding from the Astar treasury. They have been supporting Astar since it was known as Plasm Network and are committed to providing the best uptime and additional services. Their current request is for $1980 (equivalent to 330$/month) in ASTR for Q1 & Q2 2023, to cover server costs and support for their Snapshot service. This service is intended for collator nodes, helping them quickly come back online due to pruning 1000 being set. The service is updated daily and there's no cancellation period from Stakecraft's side. You can contact them at support@stakecraft.com or on Telegram @urb4n_thr34t. They have provided links to their GitHub and website for more information about the Astar & Shiden Snapshot service.

The text discusses a governance election for the decentralized finance project, SushiSwap ($SUSHI). The election is to select multi-sig wallet owners who will manage and guide $SUSHI within the industry. Their responsibilities include organizing future votes, deploying contract changes, managing treasury, and grants. A community vote may later replace the multi-sig owners with a DAO mechanism. The election is open to any SushiSwap-Ethereum liquidity pool stakeholders, and the top 9 candidates will each hold one key, requiring 6 keys for contract changes. Adam Scochran is one of the nominated candidates.

Venus prioritizes a balanced tokenomics model for protocol development and growth. The core token, XVS, governs the protocol and captures its primary value. A Venus Vault has been established to distribute staking rewards, ensure equal benefits and responsibilities for XVS holders, and capture most of the system's income.

XVS deposited in the vault receives staking rewards, voting rights, and income distributions. Deposits are subject to a 7-day unlock period, cannot be used as collateral for borrowing, and may contribute up to 10% during a risk event if the Venus risk fund is insufficient.

VRT can also be deposited in the Vault to earn an APY of 3%. After a 12-month transition period, undistributed VRT tokens will be burned. The incentive policies related to XVS deposits have changed with the launch of the Venus vault.

The Venus Vault mechanism improves the system's anti-risk ability and distributes staking rewards. All income is first deposited into Venusâ€™s treasury account, with potential sources being interest reserve and liquidation fees. Income distribution ratios can be adjusted based on risk assessment.

VRT has two primary uses: direct exchange to XVS at a 1:12000 ratio or deposit in the Vault to earn 3% APR. After a 360-day period, neither redemption nor income distribution will be available, and VRT will no longer have practical uses.

The Venus team expects this document to serve as a starting point for the dynamic growth of the protocol. They are recruiting more talents to achieve faster growth under the new tokenomics model.

The text discusses the roadmap for Starknet, a blockchain platform, in 2024. The focus has shifted from fee reduction and performance to User Experience (UX) and developer experience (devX). Key updates include:

1. v0.13.2 (August): Parallel execution, SNAR & block-packing aim at reducing confirmation time to around 2 seconds and increasing the execute limit to over 10 million steps.
2. v0.13.3 (October/November): Integration of Cairo-native, improving performance, and potential addition of nonce channels, try/catch for function call failures, and L2 gas.
3. v0.14.0 (January/February): Volition, zkThreads, mempool, protocol-level paymaster are candidates for this update, but details are yet to be decided.

The updates aim to significantly improve confirmation times, making transactions faster and more efficient for users and developers. The team encourages contributions and ideas from the community.

The author proposes an idea for a token airdrop system using transformers in a blockchain context. They suggest triggering the airdrop when users purchase a minimal amount of tokens on an exchange. However, they express concern about the potential issue of unrelated orders being logged due to the dynamic balance of Flash wallets during atomic operations. The author is seeking a solution that allows passing order context and checking if it was filled during current transformation, in order to accurately log the result to an airdrop smart contract.

The text discusses tax implications for Aragon Association (AA) if funds are transferred to a Network DAO. Currently, AA benefits from a favorable tax ruling with an effective rate of 5%, but this could change if the AA is deemed as "de-facto liquidated" upon transferring funds to a DAO outside its control. The potential tax liability for such a transaction could be up to CHF 19.5 million compared to CHF 1.16 million if the AA continues to spend funds in the current manner.

The author suggests creating a legal wrapper (Swiss Association) for the Aragon Network DAO to comply with taxation requirements, provide limited liability to participants, and enable contracting with other entities. The Swiss government offers a favorable environment for crypto projects, allowing direct communication with tax departments to find solutions. The author emphasizes the benefits of stability, transparency, and voting rights that a Swiss Association can offer.

The proposal MIP40c3-SP89 aims to modify the Core Unit (CU) budget of DECO (Decentralized Credit Operations). If approved, the budget will end on May 31st, stopping the streaming of Dai to DECO and ending the vesting of MKR to DECO CU members. This decision is due to significant changes in the DAO's needs and resources over the past three years, and DECO's evolving role within the context of the endgame. The proposal gives DECO time to propose a new budget and goals that best utilize MakerDAO's scarce resources and technical talent. The budget has been marked as obsolete due to changes introduced in MIP102c2-SP1.

The text provides information about the submission process for Core Unit Maker Improvement Proposals (MIPs). The deadline for submitting MIPs for the March Governance Monthly Cycle is February 3rd, and they will go through a Request for Comment (RFC) phase for a month. Key MIPs required are MIP39c2, MIP40c2, and MIP41c4. For support on submission, contact @charlesstlouis, @longforwisdom or @Davidutro. The complete process is outlined in the MIP Lifecycle section of MIP0. A MIP proposal begins when it's posted on the Maker forum and needs to be submitted to the MIPs Discourse Forum and Github repository. After the RFC phase, MKR holders vote on whether to include the MIP in the governance poll, ultimately determining its acceptance or rejection. The next deadline for the April Governance Cycle is March 10th.

The text discusses the evolution of Pancakeswap, a decentralized exchange platform, over time. Initially, it gained popularity due to its high APRs and passive income opportunities through cake locking. However, with the introduction of the Ultra Sound Money project, there was a significant decrease in locked cakes, leading many investors to leave. Recently, millions of cakes have been transferred to third-party projects for their benefits and rewards. The text concludes by proposing three potential community decisions:

1) Increase rewards and passive income with reduced deflation
2) Dramatically increase rewards and passive income while maintaining a balanced total supply (additional minted cakes burned for deflation would be rewarded to veCake shares)
3) Maintain the current state, neither increasing rewards nor altering deflation.

In November and December, the Recovery One Foundation, a key partner in the Harmony ecosystem, has been discussing potential solutions for users impacted by the Horizon Bridge Hack that occurred in June 2022. The loss was approximately $100 million. A proposal titled "AAVE V3 Harmony Recovery ONE Proposal Governance" was made to address the bad debt incurred by the Aave protocol on the Harmony network due to the hack. The proposal aimed to remove the bad debt and compensate AAVE holders by creating a fund and allowing token exchange. However, a 'Temp Check' snapshot vote in December was unsuccessful. The community is encouraged to continue discussing potential solutions for affected users.

A U.K. task force has proposed a new dispute resolution framework for cryptocurrency and smart contract disputes, aiming to keep these disagreements out of court. The laws would enable an independent tribunal to adjudicate on matters of dispute, with their decisions being legally binding.

The text discusses two articles from More Equal Animals, a platform that explores democratic ideas. The first article, published on August 27, 2020, suggests that if we could design a game to test skills related to good governance, it would serve as a better proxy for leader selection than the current party-politics system. It emphasizes that a skilled consensus builder is ideal for leading a government, with the least skilled being one who divides populations into warring factions.

The second article, published on March 7, 2021, discusses the concept of subjective decentralization. Instead of focusing on signs of decentralization within a single chain, it suggests that freedom of movement between chains is the true source of individual freedom. The author argues that each individual should take responsibility for decentralizing their political and economic risks, with true decentralization starting at the individual level.

Lastly, the text mentions the release of a book titled "More Equal Animals - The Subtle Art of True Democracy" on January 15, 2021. This book explores new democratic processes designed to encourage consensus building rather than political division.

The Avalanche Bridge, which uses Intel SGX technology, has become a key piece of infrastructure for the Avalanche community. BTC.b is already integrated into multiple DeFi protocols within the Avalanche ecosystem. The proposal highlights the bridge's security, cost-effectiveness, speed, transparency, and user-friendliness as driving factors. The text also provides details about Ava Labs, the servicing firm behind the Avalanche blockchain, and the current usage of BTC.b.

"Steakwallet is a user-friendly mobile crypto wallet, aiming to simplify DeFi participation across various blockchains. The team plans to integrate Curve into their wallet over 12 weeks, focusing on UX design and development. They seek a $50k grant for this project."

The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) is expected to release updated guidelines on cryptocurrencies, potentially shaping global Anti-Money Laundering (AML) frameworks for Decentralized Finance (DeFi). This development could significantly impact MakerDAO due to its potential effects on the competitive landscape.

Regulation of stablecoins, with Dai as a key focus, is one such area. Ongoing international and national discussions will determine the future of Dai as a widely available asset. Central bank digital currencies are also relevant in this context.

Regulatory scrutiny on DeFi, given Maker's role as a major player, could have substantial effects on its growth. Potential threats include securities and banking laws. New approaches to regulating DeFi are also being considered, with discussions ongoing about understanding and managing DeFi within existing regulatory frameworks.

AML/KYC and sanctions regimes, particularly in light of the FATF's upcoming guidelines, are a pressing concern for Maker (and all DeFi). Proposed regulations may challenge DeFi's anonymity while enforcing financial transaction transparency.

These points offer a basic overview of the challenges, opportunities, and trends facing Maker in the context of regulatory developments. Further discussion is encouraged to expand on these topics and help shape Maker's strategy and action items.

The proposal is for the Aragon Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) to fund a series of operational bounties aimed at transitioning various tasks from the core team to community contributors. The team leading this initiative includes Ben Perez, Alex Clay, Taylor Rawlings, and Lion, who are all members of the Aragon Core team and will not be compensated as this falls within their respective roles.

The requested funding is 14,254 ANT (equivalent to $64,143 USD on January 24, 2022), which will be escrowed with Greet.me. The funds will be used for the creation and maintenance of a bounty board, payment of ongoing and new bounties, tool subscriptions, and other miscellaneous expenses.

The budget breakdown includes funding for the genesis bounty board ($16,300), ongoing and anticipated new bounties at 1.25x Request 1 ($20,375), anticipated new bounties at 1.25x Request 2 and transition of some bounties to a collaborative incentive mechanism (Coordinape) ($25,468), and adhoc funds for tool subscriptions and other expenses ($2,000).

The risks associated with this proposal include unpredictable contributor contributions, unpredictable contribution scopes, and executional risk due to the team's lack of experience in these operational areas. The team aims to promote decentralization and avoid becoming a central point of failure or bottleneck.

The ownership, licensing, or control of any outputs is expected to be limited as most outputs are anticipated to align closely with the AN DAO operations. The team will provide regular updates to the ESD (Ethereum Name Service) on progress and cover any IP-related topics as they arise.

The latest version of the Compound protocol has a unique liquidation system compared to its predecessor. To maintain solvency, the protocol takes over borrower accounts that violate collateral requirements. Underwater borrows are repaid using the protocol's reserves. However, if the protocol reserves fall below a governance-set threshold, searchers can extract value post-liquidation.

Borrowers must maintain over-collateralization at all times in Compound III. If they accrue excessive interest or their collateral's USD value decreases significantly, or their borrow increases too much, the account becomes liquidatable. Liquidators can extract value through arbitrage during this process.

When a liquidation occurs, the borrower's collateral is moved to the protocol balance sheet and reserves are reduced to cover the borrow. Arbitrage is possible only if the protocol's reserves have been depleted below the specified threshold due to absorption. Liquidators can buy discounted collateral, sell it at market price, and pocket the difference in a single EVM transaction.

Liquidations can occur on any blockchain where Compound III is deployed. The protocol is written in Solidity and can be deployed to any EVM chain with a price feed, sufficient liquidity, and on-chain governance. Running the liquidator example code for educational purposes requires cloning the Comet repository, installing dependencies, deploying the OnChainLiquidator contract, and running a script that monitors the blockchain for liquidation opportunities.

Liquidators play a crucial role in maintaining the health of the Compound protocol by incentivizing borrowers to keep their borrows solvent. Running a successful liquidator is challenging due to competition from other searchers chasing rewards, necessitating advanced tools and optimizations.

On Tuesday, 7th November 2023 at 03:00 PM UTC / 04:00 PM CET, there will be a one-hour operation for Incaberry upgrade. The mainnet node will be updated to v0.3.3 and prover to v3.0.0. There are updates to the RPC, sequencer, and synchroniser. The network will be temporarily unavailable for approximately 2 minutes during the sequencer restart. Communication will be provided when operations resume.

It is essential to have versions v0.3.2 with Prover v3.0.0 to upgrade the network to Incaberry. Partners are recommended to update to v0.3.3. Versions v0.3.1 with Prover v2.2.2 and earlier will become obsolete. After the Tuesday update, infrastructure partners should follow instructions to update to node v0.3.3. The required resources can be found on GitHub.

Title: 3D Animated Project for BAYC NFT Holders

Description: This project aims to bring the profile pictures (PFPs) of 25 selected Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) NFT holders to life in a series of 25 animated videos. The selection process will be conducted through a post on either the ApeCoin DAO account or our own DecentStudio account on social media.

Timeline: Week 2-4 (since transfer of funds) - Video Submission & Production

Cost: $5000 (25x$200 per video pipeline and animated video)

Key Performance Indicator (KPI): Delivery of 25 animated videos to the selected BAYC NFT holders.

Platforms: Jotfrom, Decentstudio.io, Google Drive

Participant Involvement:
1. Video Acquisition for Movement Mimicking: Participants will submit their videos through JotForm, ensuring they adhere to the provided guidelines for optimal results in animation.
2. 3D Model Rigging: Correct rigging of 3D models in Blender to ensure compatibility with our technology and produce the animation.
3. Animation Enhancement with AI: Using the submitted video, we will animate the rigged 3D model by mimicking the actor's movements and enhancing the process using AI technology.
4. Delivery of Final Product: The final .mp4 video will be uploaded to Google Drive for easy access and secure storage.

Reporting Expectations:
1. After week one, a report will be sent regarding the selection of winners and PFPs that will be animated in a Google Docs format.

Title: Discussion on the Current State of AAVE Direct Deposit DAI Module

The text discusses the current state of the AAVE Direct Deposit DAI Module, highlighting its risks and potential consequences for MakerDAO. The volatile market environment has exposed AAVE as a high-risk platform due to its large exposure to stETH and cross-collateralization, which allows locked collateral to be taken out by other borrowers. Additionally, operating on multiple chains increases the risk of centralized bridge failure.

The current AAVE-DAI pool has sufficient reserves for MakerDAO to withdraw, but if DAI reserves become empty, they could be quickly snapped up by bots, potentially locking MakerDAO's liquidity for an extended period. This could cause issues with the surplus buffer, although it is a small percentage of total MakerDAO TVL (Total Value Locked).

The text suggests that the Stability Fee rate in Maker and AAVE are currently equal, so turning off the D3M (Direct Deposit Module) would not cause issues. However, this could lead to a decrease in DAI deposits via the AAVE D3M and a subsequent decrease in income for Maker.

The text concludes with a poll asking whether to temporarily set the AAVE D3M Debt Ceiling to 0 (Zero), with options being Yes, No, or Abstain. As of the time of writing, no votes have been cast, and the poll will close on June 20, 2022, at 17:00 UTC. The text encourages MKR token owners, community members, and Delegates to gather data and analysis to help MakerDAO make an informed decision.

1. Pendle Yield Market: To increase Starknet's attractiveness, consider implementing a yield market similar to Pendle, which could potentially offer a significant airdrop for users. This would align with the expectation of a Jito-like airdrop and help boost Starknet's popularity.

2. Connecting Starknet to Hyperlane: Integrating Starknet with Hyperlane could have several benefits, such as increased integration with Ethereum and other chains, faster bridging, and potential exposure to Hyperlane's user base. This could help drive more traffic to Starknet and increase its overall attractiveness.

3. DEX and Money Markets: Developing a ve(3,3) DEX or an order-book DEX like Mangrove Exchange could help boost TVL, volume, and reputation for Starknet. These innovations could also potentially lead to higher returns for users.

4. Unruggable Memecoin Platform: Enhancing the Unruggable platform to resemble Pinksale, with live charts and other user-friendly features, could help attract more users interested in memecoins.

5. Leverage Farming Protocol/Autocompounder: Developing a leverage farming protocol or an autocompounder like Alpaca or Beefy could be beneficial when fees decrease and there is more hype around these types of DeFi services.

6. Delta-Neutral Stablecoin: Creating a delta-neutral stablecoin such as Ethena could help extend the utility of Starknet, but it may not be the first priority given the current focus on other areas of development.

7. Innovation: Developing new and exciting features for Starknet, such as Kakarot zkEVM or Madara, could help attract users and keep them engaged. This could also help differentiate Starknet from other platforms and increase its overall appeal.

The text discusses revisions to Badger emissions for Q2 2022. The changes include allocating up to 8k Badger per week for testing new emissions programs or bribing, maintaining DIGG emissions at the same level as Q1 2022, and reducing Badger emissions in other areas.

The main focus is on keeping Badger emissions for ibBTC and bcvxCRV on Ethereum, renBTC and Badger/WBTC on Arbitrum, and removing emissions from the rest. The net result is a 28% reduction in emissions.

The text also mentions that the bveCVX restructure has made the vault profitable and self-sustainable, creating regular buy pressure for Badger and supporting the distribution of CVX and CRV yields to BADGER/WBTC on Convex. The treasury will no longer spend Badger emissions on incentivizing bveCVX/CVX or Badger/WBTC on Sushi as it is now self-sustainable.

The goal for non-BTC vaults is to make them profitable, and the BTC vault profitability is something they plan to refocus on later in the year. The treasury may use DIGG from its liquidity or mint new DIGG for emissions in 2022. The vote is open for approval of these changes.

The Venus Protocol experienced an unanticipated Chainlink LUNA price feed suspension, affecting several protocols including Venus. The incident occurred on May 12 at approximately 09:20 UTC, causing a price disparity and suspicious account deposits. To mitigate the impact, the team paused the protocol and negotiated with BNB Accelerator Fund for an immediate loan to cover liquidity. The shortfall will be covered by Venus Risk Fund over time. Future incidents will be addressed by implementing robust monitoring, fallback feeds, and fail-safe mechanisms for individual markets. The protocol is expected to resume operating in 48 hours after governance timelock approval. Liquidity incentives are planned for XVS holders. Venus invites professionals to join its team and encourages community engagement on Discord.

The text discusses a proposed campaign aimed at increasing participation in MKR governance voting by offering tickets to DAIvinity events as rewards. The campaign targets small MKR holders, defined as those with less than 50 MKR, and will run from August 17 to October 1. To qualify, participants must vote in a minimum number of unique polls (to be determined) and not exceed 50 MKR per vote. The tickets will be distributed based on the number of polls voted and the time the final vote was cast. Ineligible addresses include recognized delegates, addresses with more than 50 MKR voting, and shadow delegates.

The campaign aims to increase small MKR holder participation, promote MKR procurement and governance voting, boost social media chatter about MKR voting and Maker in general, and increase the representation of MKR holders at DAIvinity events. The cons of the campaign include voters potentially voting without considering the vote's implications and some un-delegation as people who delegate may not qualify. However, these downsides are expected to be minimal due to eligibility limits.

The campaign will have an RFC period from August 10-17 for any feedback or suggestions, followed by a contest announcement via Twitter on August 17. Tickets will be sent through etherscan to qualifying addresses on October 2, and they must be claimed by October 7th or they will be forfeited. The pros of the campaign include direct incentives for small MKR holders to vote, encouraging new voters and holders, growing governance voter participation, and potentially increasing active users on the MKR forum.

This draft proposes a redelegation policy for funds unstaked due to underperforming validators by the Polygon Foundation. The policy aims to incentivize and motivate small, well-performing validators by redistributing these funds to them. This action benefits Polygon's decentralization and security as it reduces the inequality of validating power among validators.

The proposal suggests redelegating the funds to active validators not in GP1 or GP2, with a focus on smaller validators due to their positive impact on network decentralization. The criteria for redelegation candidates include health status and small validator status.

The Polygon Foundation should consider redelegating these funds instead of keeping them in the treasury or using them to bootstrap newly onboarding validators. A poll will be conducted to determine the percentage (x) of smaller, active validators that should receive the redistributed funds equally. The proposal is open for feedback and suggestions to improve its final form.

Title: Proposal to Add dlcBTC/WBTC Gauge on Arbitrum's Gauge Controller

   Author: Aki Balogh

   Overview: This proposal aims to incorporate the dlcBTC/WBTC pool gauge into the Gauge Controller on Ethereum's Arbitrum network. The proposal seeks to provide deep liquidity for both dlcBTC and WBTC, enhancing their usage within DeFi and supporting broader adoption of decentralized Bitcoin solutions in DeFi.

   Key Details:
   - dlcBTC is a decentralized wrapped Bitcoin on Ethereum, leveraging Discreet Log Contracts (DLCs) for secure cross-chain transactions. It operates as an oracle-free system with minimal parameters and maintains a soft peg of 1 BTC = 1 dlcBTC.
   - WBTC is a tokenized version of Bitcoin on Ethereum, backed 1:1 by Bitcoin and managed by a consortium of custodians and merchants. It introduces counterparty risk as funds are held in centralized custody by BitGo.

   Rationale: Incentivizing the dlcBTC/WBTC pool will promote liquidity, improve trading experience, and foster a more robust DeFi ecosystem. DLC.Link has committed to co-incentivizing the pool.

   Governance: dlcBTC operates with minimal governance, utilizing a Chainlink proof of reserve feed for transparency and a custom oracle combining two NG pools. Audits have been conducted by Lightpaper & Audit Reports, MetaTrust, CoinFabrik, and others.

   Centralization Vectors: The dlcBTC protocol has no major centralization vectors as depositors' Bitcoin is secured in a Discreet Log Contract (DLC) and mint/burn signals are relayed through DLC.Linkâ€™s Attestor network.

   Market History: dlcBTC is supported by initial merchants, with additional merchants set to contribute significantly. It has passed the first of three proposals to list as collateral on Aave. Voting for its inclusion is currently live.

GovAlpha, a core unit at MakerDAO, acknowledges recent criticism regarding communication and governance process. The governance process ultimately lies in the hands of MKR holders, and GovAlpha will continue to voice opinions on proposals that seek to change governance processes or structures.

The proposed MIP113 outlines a process for improving the Scope Artifact within the MakerDAO ecosystem. This process involves the Governance Facilitators soliciting proposals from Advisory Council (AVC) members each quarter, with the goal of finding suitable individuals to perform projects that will improve the Scope Artifact. The work output from these projects is intended to be presented to the AVC Subcommittee Meetings as input for their Aligned Scope Proposals.

The timeline for this process requires the Governance Facilitators to determine a limited process, trigger necessary votes and forum posts, and have a budget and Ecosystem Actors approved by August 1, 2023, with a deliverable due by September 1, 2023. The budget for Advisory Council projects is available per quarter, with all spending being limited to what is deemed necessary and likely to produce measurable value. This spending must be transparently accounted for in a forum post at least a week before any transaction occurs.

The proposed process meets the requirements of GOV 9 and AVC requirements regarding Scope Bootstrapping. During the bootstrapping phase, AVCs are expected to focus on making Aligned Scope Proposals that improve the Scope Improvement Articles. However, a foundation must first be laid by domain experts who can collaborate with Scope Facilitators to identify high-value areas of improvement in the Scopes. Once this foundation has been established, AVCs can take over the quarterly improvement process as currently envisioned in the Atlas.

The text discusses a proposal to adjust Synapse DAO emissions for capital efficiency and cheaper quote usage without SYN spend. AragonDAO's Umbrella Team, in partnership with GravityDAO, is launching a Conflict Management Training course starting June 23rd. This series of five workshops, held bi-weekly, will focus on practical conflict management skills and aim to establish an internal team for managing conflicts within the AN DAO ecosystem. Topics include transforming conflict, deep democracy, liberating structures, wellbeing in workspaces, burnout, and psychology, and roleplay. The workshops will be hosted on Aragon's Discord server, with additional campfire discussions focusing on related topics. For more information, visit the Umbrella Initiative page on Notion.

The MATIC token is used for gas fees on the Polygon network, supports DApps, and can be staked to earn APY.

In the AAVE ecosystem, MATIC can be lent to boost liquidity or borrowed by Ether depositors on lucrative interest rates to capture liquidity pools of the growing DeFi ecosystem on Polygon. The overall risk of MATIC is B+ with smart contract, counterparty, and market risks rated B, B+, and C respectively. The text proposes an improvement to the stablecoin Dai by decoupling its value from the inflation factor of fiat currencies like the US Dollar. This change would make Dai less affected by fluctuations in the dollar's value and protect it from inflation, making it more attractive for investors and institutions seeking stability. However, this could lead to a temporary decrease in circulation due to increased interest rates. The author suggests that if this modification isn't feasible for Dai, a new stablecoin with anti-inflationary features could be created. The potential disadvantages include a slowdown in adoption due to higher interest rates and reduced attractiveness for users borrowing Dai to invest in other cryptocurrencies. The author also mentions the possibility of creating an experimental version of this new stablecoin, similar to Kusama in the Polkadot ecosystem. The text implies that the dollar's future inflation forecasts are negative, raising questions about the long-term health of Maker (the organization behind Dai) if inflation becomes significant.

The document outlines a proposed policy for managing the BadgerDAO treasury, including new smart contract operations, investment categories, and guidelines for valuing investments. Here's a summary:

1. New smart contract operations should be tested in the Tech Ops Multisig before being executed at scale in the Treasury Ops Multisig.
2. Assets that fall under Venture Investments, Strategic Holdings, or Acquisitions categories should be considered to have priority to be held in the Treasury Multisig.
3. Treasury Controlled Liquidity, such as BIP 74, is also included.
4. Each investment must have a written thesis made public within 24 hours of any approved action taken by the investment council. The thesis should include qualitative and quantitative statements about the investment's potential success or failure metrics and risks.
5. Success or failure will be measured by increase/decrease in value in the treasury, TVL, Badger token price, number of Badger token holders, and various risk factors such as protocol, liquidity, market, credit, and execution risk.
6. Any holding above 5% at the end of a quarter must be rebalanced unless vetoed by BadgerDAO token holders in a BIP. There will be a wiggle room of 2.5%.
7. The investment thesis should propose an investment governance approach, including interim milestones, profit-taking strategy, and management responsibilities.
8. A vote is proposed to enact the General Treasury Policy and appoint the Treasury Investment Council as described above.

The document also mentions that the investment council should consider scaling in or out of investments based on interim milestones and market dynamics. The profit-taking strategy could involve liquidating at the end of the time horizon, renewing through another vote, or DCA (Dollar Cost Averaging) in and taking profits along the way. The management of the investment should be clearly defined, with any additional approvals required to make moves specified.

The text discusses issues with the current Cake interest rate model on the Venus platform. The external staking reward is higher than borrowing rates, leading to a lack of liquidity for the asset as people exploit this difference. A proposed alternative suggests reducing the hard cap on borrowing Cake and using deposited Cake liquidity to farm Cake rewards within Venus, similar to autofarm or beefy. This approach aims to solve liquidity issues, generate substantial profits for the platform, and provide benefits such as buying back XVS, addressing bad debt, covering bot costs, purchasing insurance, and countering black-swan events. The goal is to optimize asset utilization and increase profits for Venus while setting a new precedent in lending platforms.

Title: Partnership Mining Initiative Proposal

   The proposal, drafted by @immutbl, @tongnk, and Oaksprout, is a community-driven initiative to boost collaborations and integrations benefiting the Balancer protocol. Known as "Partnership Mining," it incentivizes a network of crypto enthusiasts, or "partnership miners," to identify potential partnerships, propose ideas, and execute value-adding integrations.

   The Balancer Ecosystem Team will manage this initiative, offering assistance when needed. Successful proposals receive BAL rewards proportional to the impact of the partnership. Proposals will be evaluated based on criteria such as software integration potential, clear plans for increasing trading volume or TVL, legitimacy, open-source nature, and no prior contact with the Balancer Ecosystem Team.

   The initiative is structured as a trial, favoring capital-light proposals during this phase. Rewards are calculated based on trading fees generated since launch, capped at $20k USD equivalent after six months. If the program generates more than 1% of the protocol's revenue within a year following the trial period, it may be extended.

   Potential improvements include extending fee rewards duration, increasing initial reward amounts, introducing higher reward tiers for BAL vesting, and boosting competitiveness with performance-based reward multipliers.

The text discusses StableLab's proposal for a Delegate Reward program in Uniswap DAO, aimed at incentivizing and rewarding active delegates. The proposed 6-month program has a total budget of $600K in UNI. The rewards will be determined based on three main factors: Voting Participation, Communication, and Badge Ownership. To be eligible for the rewards, delegates should have contributed for at least 3 months and meet an 80% participation and communication benchmark. A badge system is proposed to make the program more inclusive, where delegates with 500,000 UNI or above can apply for a Delegate Reward if they fulfill the requirements, while those with less than 500,000 UNI can also apply with endorsement from delegates with 500,000 UNI +. The budget is $600,000 worth of UNI for 6 months, with StableLab overseeing the program without receiving delegate compensation to prevent double-budgeting. The proposal is open to community feedback and suggestions for improvement before it moves to an offchain vote.

Title: Proposal for Gauge for inwBETH/wBETH on Ethereum by InceptionLRT

   Summary: The proposal aims to establish a gauge for the pairing of inwBETH and wBETH on Ethereum, with inwBETH being a Restaked Token dedicated to wBETH obtained through InceptionLRT's restaking mechanism. InceptionLRT is an isolated Liquid Restaking protocol designed for Liquid Staking Tokens (LSTs), issuing Isolated Liquid Restaking Tokens (iLRTs) for each restaked LST. These iLRTs can be traded and used in DeFi protocols while maintaining segregation from the underlying LSTs. The goal is to increase liquidity of inwBETH, support its utility, and integrate it into various DeFi protocols.

   References:
   - Website: https://www.inceptionlrt.com/
   - Documentation: https://docs.inceptionlrt.com/
   - Github Page: https://github.com/inceptionlrt/smart-contracts/tree/master
   - Communities: Twitter: https://twitter.com/InceptionLRT, Discord: https://discord.com/invite/gBswunawAn

   Key Features:
   - Governance: ING holders participate in decision-making.
   - Incentive Allocation: veING holders direct incentives and rewards.
   - Oracles: Rate Provider for inwBETH.
   - Audits: Security audits to ensure user fund safety.
   - Centralization vectors: Vision for decentralization through independent node operators.
   - Market History: No major volatility.

The text discusses initial benchmarks for allocating assets in a DAI vault on Morpho, focusing on the USDe and sUSDe pools. Exposure limits are set based on open interest, DAI circulating supply, and total USDe supply, with tail risk mitigation as the primary constraint. The target borrow rate increases as exposure grows to compensate Maker for increased risk. Moderate LLTV (Liquidation Loss Tolerance Value) pools of 86% and 91.5% are considered to offer the best risk-adjusted return, with higher yields from higher LLTV pools but less favorable risk vs reward. The text concludes that new allocations should be made into USDe pools, with a plan to reevaluate this relative split regularly. Future steps include improving the vault rate benchmarking methodology, implementing intra-vault optimization heuristics, and defining milestones for increasing exposure based on improvements in Ethena's transparency, resilience, and risk factors.

In this text, the author is discussing the global protests that have taken place since 2017, focusing on the potential for decentralized autonomous movements (DAM) to bring about significant change. The author argues that while protests can lead to important changes, they often fall short of achieving their long-term, fundamental goals due to a lack of self-organization and appropriate infrastructure.

The author proposes that the solution lies in harnessing the collective energy of protest movements and transforming them into self-organized forces capable of achieving desired outcomes. To do this, the author suggests focusing on developing the necessary infrastructure, concepts, and strategies to support these movements. The author also suggests that this effort should be undertaken on a global scale, as protests and issues related to change can be found everywhere.

The author acknowledges that they do not have all the answers and invites others to join in finding solutions. They propose taking practical steps towards achieving their vision and are ready to take action themselves. The author's general opinion is that their thinking is in the right direction, but they welcome feedback on whether these ideas are excessive dreams or not.

Overall, the text highlights the potential for protests to bring about change and the need to develop appropriate infrastructure and strategies to support these movements in achieving their long-term goals. The author invites others to join in finding solutions to this challenge.

A TLOS-BNB farm will also be provided for hosting the pool, offering 1x CAKE rewards for the first 48 hours and then 0.5x CAKE rewards thereafter.

Telos is a fast and scalable blockchain focused on real-world use and adoption. It hosts over 100 distinct applications and will soon have the most performant and affordable Ethereum Virtual Machine available.

To learn more about Telos, visit their official communication channels. To stake CAKE for TLOS rewards, follow the steps provided on the PancakeSwap website. Be cautious as only the official TLOS token contract address on Binance Smart Chain should be used to avoid scams.

The Super Symbiotic LRT aims to facilitate easy onboarding of ether.fi customers into the Symbiotic ecosystem, a shared security protocol that empowers network builders. Unlike other LRTs, users have multiple deposit options including WETH, eETH, weETH, wstETH, cbETH, bETH, rETH, mETH, swETH, etc. The weETHs LRT allows users to stake ETH, accrue staking rewards, and receive additional rewards through native restaking on Symbiotic. The Aragon Network Token (ANT) has been added as a collateral asset to UMA, enabling its use in the creation of KPI options for the Aragon community. These KPI options are synthetic tokens that reward holders if certain predetermined targets are met before a specified expiry date. To incentivize Aragon DAOs to transition from v1 to v2, KPI options will be distributed to all v1 DAOs after creation, with the ability to redeem them for ANT collateral at option expiry. The amount of collateral that can be redeemed depends on the DAO's proportional share of AUM and the speed of upgrading to v2.

A test of KPI options is being proposed, with potential expansion if successful. Key details include a contract start date (7th April 2021) and end date (30th June 2021), the KPI being total value of assets in all V2 DAOs by the end date, and the use of a bonding curve to incentivize early adopters of v2. A draft of planned votes is posted for community review, with votes on the amount of ANT to be used as collateral and an upper threshold for USD AUM in V2 DAOs by the end date.

The Aragon Academy is a project initiated by Aragon China DAO to educate people about Aragon, a complex blockchain platform. The goal is to launch the academy in China, reaching over 1.4 billion people who are unfamiliar with crypto and blockchain. The academy will consist of a series of courses, tutorials, and certifications spread out over 10 levels, starting from complete newbies and progressing to Aragon experts.

The MVP (Minimum Viable Product) is Level 1: Introduction to Aragon, featuring three video-based courses with on-chain challenges. Completion of these challenges will award the Level 1 certification. The project is a long-term plan, with short-term goals including building the website and inviting experts to create videos.

The funding required for this project is $5K, which will be managed by all DAO members and used to build the website and invite experts. More details about how funds will be handled and used are available in the provided Ethereum address. The project's progress can be tracked on the Aragon China website, forum, and DAO.

Valerian is a sustainable DeFi-NFT ecosystem on Astar Network, offering high APRs and unique solutions. Uniswap Labs' governance system, initially deployed on Ethereum mainnet, has also been deployed on four additional domains (Polygon, Optimism, Celo, and Arbitrum). However, the governance system for the Arbitrum deployment was misconfigured due to a communication error between developers. The Uniswap Factory on Arbitrum was deployed with an owner set to an EOA address that nobody can control, preventing governance proposals from being executed.

Arbitrum proposes a solution: a temporary exception will be added to disable address-aliasing for messages from the L1 TimeLock contract, allowing the Uniswap governance contract to send a cross-chain message and set the owner of the L2 Uniswap factory to the L1 Timelockâ€™s address alias. This will enable cross-chain governance between Uniswap and Arbitrum, strengthening their relationship. The solution involves a final governance vote, temporary exception disabling address-aliasing, sending a cross-chain message, and re-enabling aliasing for the L1 Timelock contract address.

The text discusses issues with the fee calculation on Shiden and Astar networks, specifically focusing on rent fees. Currently, the rent fee is too low compared to Polkadot due to a 100x higher initial total supply and block reward on Astar. To address this issue, an improved formula for calculating rent fees has been proposed:

* For Astar: 100 ASTR * number_of_db_entries + 0.01 ASTR * number_of_bytes
* For Shiden: 1 SDN * number_of_db_entries + 0.0001 SDN * number_of_bytes

Additionally, creating a new asset on both networks will become more expensive: 10 SDN on Shiden and 1000 ASTR on Astar. The changes aim to make the fee structure more comparable to Polkadot. Users are encouraged to share their thoughts and opinions.

This proposal aims to encourage development of a "cross-chain agent" functionality, allowing Aragon organizations on one blockchain to perform transactions on another via a bridge. The desired outcome is for an organization to vote and execute actions (e.g., purchasing ENS domains) on another chain while maintaining operations on the original. POA Network's Arbitrary Message Bridge and ChainSafe's ChainBridge are suggested as potential foundations. The rationale behind this proposal is to accommodate the growing number of organizations deploying or migrating on alternative EVM-compatible chains, offering lower transaction fees and interesting possibilities for cross-chain control. A rough proof of concept could potentially be completed in a few weeks.

In 2023, Paxos and Binance announced they would phase out BUSD over a year. The Synapse DAO has proposed shifting emissions from the "legacy" BSC Stableswap pool to a new one due to BUSD deprecation. To achieve this, the DAO plans to decrease emissions on the legacy pool and increase them on the new pool. The Aave protocol is a decentralized network of smart contracts, accessible to all with tech knowledge. To enhance user experience, the Aave companies developed the Aave application (version 4), enabling interaction with the protocol without technical expertise. Deployed on IFPS and potentially Flux hosting for decentralization, the Aave app is open-source, allowing developers to contribute.

Recently, there have been demands from third parties to integrate into the Aave App (e.g., wallets, on-ramps). This proposed governance framework aims to standardize this process. Entities seeking integration must present their proposal, detailing requested integration and specific app sections for modification. They should also discuss current and proposed integration with Aave.

The governance process involves a 5-day governance thread, followed by a snapshot vote with a valid period of at least 3 days and a 100k AAVE YAE quorum. If no security issues are detected during PR review, the PR will be merged. In case of a security issue, technical communication channels will open for resolution, but the Aave interface maintainers retain veto rights if they deem the integration harmful to users' security.

Title: Refinance Automation Functionality in Instadapp's DeFi Smart Account (DSA) using Gelato

Authors: Samyak Jain, Luis Schliesske
Status: Formal Submission
Proposed Date: 2021-1-4

Instadapp and Gelato have collaborated to integrate refinance automation into Instadapp's DeFi Smart Account (DSA), which are permissionless and non-custodial. This update allows users to set up refinance automation for ETH-A vaults in case of liquidation across Aave, ETH-B, or Compound. The process prioritizes refinancing as follows:

1. Aave (if no DAI liquidity)
2. ETH-B vault (if ceiling reached)
3. Compound

The automation works in two modes:
- Without oracle data: Users set a ratio for refinancing ETH-A vaults.
- With oracle data: Refinancing occurs only when the ETH-A vault is about to get liquidated.

The Maker Oracle feed is used to acquire and verify price data, ensuring secure automation for DSA users. The contract (ConditionMakerVaultUnsafe.sol) does not store or return the ETH/USD price; it processes the price in-memory and returns either "OK" or "NOT OK". If "OK", the Gelato bots automatically refinance the debt position.

The oracle data is permission-only to the contract, ensuring it meets whitelisting requirements. The involved contracts are Instadapp (samyak@instadapp.io) and Gelato (luis@gelato.digital). The contract to be whitelisted is ConditionMakerVaultUnsafe.sol â€“ 0x3b50336E3E1E618FE74DF351966ebaD2B12cD24a.

Requirements include verified source code on etherscan, permission-based usage of oracle data to prevent parasitic behavior, and no storage of oracle data. Fees are waived for the first year, with fees determined by MKR Governance after that.

Vitalik Buterin, Ethereum co-founder, suggests that token-based governance in DeFi is a hindrance and advocates for exploring "Proof-of-Humanity"-based systems. He proposes "Proof-of-Participation," quadratic voting, and optimistic/lazy governance as potential solutions. Coin voting fails due to lack of individual accountability. Other proposed solutions include Conviction Voting, delegating coins to trusted users, staking coins for increased voting power, and gaining reputation through participation.
Require help to upgrade ANTv1 tokens to ANTv2 using ImToken wallet.

The Treasury is divesting its AURA holdings and swapping them into ETH due to reduced yields and potential future governance by BADGER token holders. The initial investment in AURA was made because it was distributing significantly more value than its trading price, but this has changed over time. The treasury will use a ladder order strategy to minimize slippage and execute the order over several days if necessary. The decision reduces protocol risk, has moderate market risk, minimal liquidity risk, no credit risk, and execution risk of 2 out of 10.

Topics discussed: Snapshot voting and Aragon organization, demonstrations of Snapshot flow, 1Hive swap, and statistics. Key points include the creation of a Snapshot space within an Aragon organization, addition of an Agreement plugin, off-chain voting using disputable delay app, and Honeyswap (a Uniswap v2 fork for xDai network) with associated statistics.

The Governance Fund Phase 1 proposal is eligible for voting in Cycle 8, which marks the end of Season 2. This proposal was reviewed by the Tooling Committee and their recommendations can be found on the governance platform. The Token House has delegated decision-making to official committees but delegates may vote against committee recommendations, requiring justification to the community.

1. The new code for Easy Track will be deeply audited, while only the updated sections are relevant for this process. A single general payout contract will be used across all committees, promoting transparency and security.

2. Limits will be checked at both the creation and enactment of a Motion (Option 2). This ensures that potential issues are addressed early in the process, but still allows users to proceed with caution if necessary. If a motion is created on the border of periods or involves different tokens, the total budget limit for the new period will be used for verification. A warning will be issued if there's a possibility that the motion may not pass.

3. To manage budgets in different tokens, it is proposed to check budgets using spot exchange rates and Chainlink pricefeeds (Option 3). This will allow for flexible spending across various tokens while maintaining accuracy and security. An EVMScriptFactory will be deployed for each committee, with limit parameters and checks either built into the factory's bytecode or leveraging an external oracle-like contract.

In summary, the proposed solution involves checking limits at both the start and enactment of a Motion, using spot exchange rates to manage budgets across different tokens, and deploying a generalized EVMScriptFactory for making payments with built-in limit checks or leveraging an external oracle-like contract.
A proposal to add a Dai, USDC, USD Tether pool (DUSD 3Pool) metapool on Curve Finance is discussed. The aim is to improve liquidity and trading efficiency for stablecoins.

This proposal aims to increase the community-preferred supply cap limit for Liquidity Staking Tokens (LSTs) from 75% to 90% of the total supply. The rationale behind this is the growth of Aave and the strong demand for new liquid restaking tokens (LRT). Aave has become a significant hub for LRT supply, driving demand on various chains. With longer market presence and reduced risk from secondary market volatility, this proposal suggests raising the community preference supply cap limit to 90%. The change will be made through an ARFC process, with feedback collected before an ARFC snapshot. If passed, the new limit will become canon and risk service providers will update their recommendations accordingly.

The text discusses a proposed update, Staking Router v2.0, for Lido DAO's Ethereum staking platform. The upgrade aims to make the system more secure, scalable, and permissionless by introducing improvements in various components such as Deposit Security Module (DSM), Validator Exit Bus Oracle (VEBO), Accounting Oracle, and reward distribution mechanisms in curated-based modules.

The DSM changes aim to automate key vetting within the module to enhance security and eliminate governance approval requirements. VEBO improvements focus on allowing validators to exit for reasons other than withdrawal requests and prioritizing exits based on each module's target share. The Accounting Oracle's third phase report will be split into multiple transactions to manage large data sets efficiently, and new gas consumption limits and sanity checks will be implemented. Lastly, reward distribution in curated-based modules will be decoupled from the third-phase Oracle finalization hook for efficient processing without exceeding gas constraints.

The community is encouraged to stay updated on testnet deployments, as the changes will undergo security audits before a mainnet proposal. Detailed specifications can be found in LIP-25 on GitHub.
The text discusses a staking pool with a fixed term. It asks for the preferred locked time period of the user when participating in this staking pool.

Polygon, formerly known as Matic, is experiencing rapid growth. Major Ethereum projects are integrating with it, including Aave and OpenSea, significantly increasing its market value to nearly $2B. The Makerdao community also seems to be aligning with Polygon. However, the Maker Protocol Engineering team is also working on a multichain strategy, which includes Polygon, Optimism, and other L2s and L1s. Relevant discussions can be found in threads from May 2021, March 2021, and July 2020.

The text discusses a proposal to incorporate PizzaX, a decentralized Binance Smart Chain application offering up to 15% daily return on investment for lifetime in its various pools (USDT, BNB, and $PizzaX), into Compound's grants program. This integration aims to enhance the simplicity, transparency, and efficiency of the grant process for both Grantors and Grantees within the Compound community. The proposal suggests that PizzaX could handle grant disbursements via Compound's existing grants system.

The text discusses the Peg Keeper system in the context of Curve Finance's crvUSD stablecoin and its potential risks. The Peg Keeper is designed to maintain the 1:1 peg between the USDC stablecoin and its corresponding crvUSD token by minting or burning crvUSD as needed. However, a concern is that if USDC depegs, excessive amounts of crvUSD may be minted, potentially leading to its devaluation.

The text highlights that the Peg Keeper's debt ceiling and aggregator mechanism are designed to prevent this issue. Simulations show that in 99% of cases, the Aggregator successfully blocks the USDC Peg Keeper from performing updates. The failure occurs only when there is more liquidity in the USDC Peg Keeper pool than all other Peg Keeper pools combined, which is an unlikely scenario due to a "flight to safety" from USDC to USDT during a depeg event.

The text suggests that diversifying the set of liquid Peg Keeper pools is crucial for risk management. This would help stabilize oracle prices in case of a stablecoin depeg and potentially require the creation of new TriCrypto-ng pools.

Future work includes extending the model to other key parameters, handling onboarding new markets, analyzing the effect of onboarding new stablecoins, expanding stress scenarios, improving model implementation, and applying the model to different market conditions and protocol parameters.

The primary contribution is developing a Curve-specific Agent-Based Model (ABM) for simulating the crvUSD protocol and identifying key risks and their potential mitigation strategies. The text acknowledges the complexity of the system and the possibility of unknown risks that may impact its accuracy. Future work may involve applying the model to different market conditions, investigating the impact of changing parameters or smart contract logic, and modifying Peg Keeper and Oracle mechanisms. Special thanks are given to several individuals for their feedback and help with implementation.

Title: Proposal to Extend Safety Module Protection to Aave V2 on Polygon
   Summary: This ARC aims to extend the Safety Module protection, a $700m risk mitigation pool, to V2 markets on Polygon. The SM currently only protects the Ethereum V2 market. By extending coverage, it is expected to reduce risk for liquidity providers and lead to growth of the market's TVL. The SM will only protect in cases where Aave smart contracts experience a failure, not failures caused by the chains themselves. The proposal suggests that these markets have become essential components of the Aave ecosystem, opening the protocol to new users and generating significant revenue.
This section holds all governance proposals for community discussion, provided there's enough community interest.
The text discusses the shape of Earth, stating that it is not flat but round, specifically an oblate spheroid due to its rotation and gravitational pull.

Title: Extend Safety Module Protection to Aave V2 Arc
   Summary: This proposal aims to extend the Safety Module (SM) protection, a $700m risk mitigation pool, to additional V2 markets in Aave. The SM currently protects only the Ethereum V2 market, leaving other markets with varying levels of risk protection. By extending SM coverage to other V2 markets, it is expected to reduce risk for liquidity providers, promote growth of TVL, and provide equal treatment across markets. However, additional risks specific to these markets need to be considered. The proposal includes Polygon and Avalanche markets, which have become significant components of the Aave ecosystem, attracting a large number of users and generating half of the protocol's revenue in a shorter time period. Voting is now open for extending SM coverage to the Aave V2 Arc Market.

The text discusses the need for monitoring tools within the Maker ecosystem, focusing on Vault users, DAI liquidity, and competitive landscape. The purpose is to gain insights into primary issuance of DAI, its flow between Automated Market Makers (AMMs) and secondary lenders, and their impact on the peg.

Key areas to monitor include:
1. Vault DAI Utilization Metrics: A live view of Vault issuance, collateralization metrics, and DAI flow. The goal is to understand user behavior and potential liquidation risks associated with certain Vaults.
2. DAI & Other Stablecoin On-chain Balances and Flows: Tracking the location of DAI and major addresses to better understand DAI flows between protocols and find new relevant addresses entering the system.
3. Competitive Landscape: Monitoring rates of secondary lenders, their product differences from Maker's, and making comparative assessments to decide on appropriate stability fees for Vault types.

The ideal candidate should have knowledge of MakerDAO's primary issuance of DAI, perform on-chain analysis on Ethereum, build a regularly updated monitoring tool, follow DeFi ecosystem developments, and be self-directed. Interested parties can reach out to @doopson (Primoz) on the MakerDAO Rocketchat for funding through the Grants Program framework. Future tasks related to risk evaluation of collateral onboarding are also planned.

The proposal aims to introduce an emergency unlock feature for CAKE tokens, allowing users to retrieve their tokens early at a penalty of 20%. This penalty amount will be burned, reducing the maximum and circulating supply of CAKE. This move is expected to boost user confidence, attract more stakers, and gradually decrease the total CAKE supply in the long term.

The text discusses the first governance elections for the decentralized finance (DeFi) project, SushiSwap ($SUSHI). The election aims to transfer ownership of the project to a multi-signature wallet, managed by nine elected candidates. These candidates are chosen from nominations within the $SUSHI community and include YFI maximalists. The multi-sig owners will be responsible for decision-making tasks such as organizing future votes, deploying contract changes, managing treasury, and grants. A potential future change could involve a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) mechanism, subject to community vote. The election is open to $SUSHI-ETH liquidity providers (LPs), and the top 9 candidates will each hold one key, requiring six keys for any changes to be made to $SUSHI.
The Treasury Council posts its decisions with explanations on a designated platform.

The text introduces Bunni v2, a platform designed to maximize returns for liquidity providers (LPs) on Uniswap v4 by utilizing advanced rehypothecation features. Key features include Shapeshifting Liquidity, Dynamic Liquidity Shifting, ERC-20 Wrapped LP Tokens, am-AMM, and rehypothecation for idle assets in liquidity positions. The rehypothecation feature is particularly beneficial for DAI LPs, allowing them to deploy idle assets into yield-generating protocols like the DSR, Aave, or Gearbox, increasing returns and TVL. Bunni v2 also offers advantages for market makers, such as open-source am-AMM implementation, Bid Dog. AllocatorDAOs can benefit from enhanced returns, increased capital efficiency, automated management, and risk mitigation by utilizing the DSR for rehypothecation. The testnet is live at Bunni.xyz, with mainnet launch planned alongside Uniswap v4.

Delegation is a system that allows veBAL holders to assign their voting power to chosen delegates via the snapshot platform. This enables participation for those who don't wish to vote themselves or have insufficient tokens. Being a delegate involves actively engaging in Balancer's governance process, providing feedback on forum posts, casting votes with explanations, and having a strong understanding of Balancer's key metrics. Delegates can improve the efficiency, transparency, and direction of the DAO by coordinating between proposal makers and big voters. Prospective delegates create a pitch in the forum to present their qualifications, and updates are expected each time they vote. The delegate role is open to individuals or organizations and may be compensated in the future.
