- Sourcecred was launched.

The proposal aims to utilize data analysis and segmentation to enhance participation in the ApeCoin Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO). By understanding the interests and behavior patterns of $APE token holders, the DAO can optimize its governance processes, fostering a more active and lively community. The total funding requested is $15,000, divided into two milestones. The Ape Foundation oversees the proposal's implementation, with the right to make changes for security, usability, or to protect token holders. Any significant deviations from the initial plan will be disclosed to the community. [Full proposal available at: https://forum.apecoin.com/t/aip-275-understanding-and-improving-the-governance-participation-in-apecoin-dao/13525]

This text discusses a new proposal (AIP-22) for the staking process of ApeCoin, which aims to reintroduce a previously rejected proposal (AIP-5). The key points are the total allocation for staking pools and a three-year duration for the staking period. The Ape Foundation will oversee the implementation of this proposal, with potential alterations made for security, usability, and protection of APE holders. Any significant deviations from the initial proposal will be disclosed to the community. For further details, refer to the full proposal at the provided link.

The text discusses the importance of a strong social layer in Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs), comparing it to a coordination layer that withstands adversity like bad weather. A robust community, built on trust and a positive work environment, can resist various challenges. An example given is the Steem community's collective action against centralization attempts.

However, a damaged social layer, characterized by mistrust or unhappiness among members, can hinder coordination and efficiency. Conflicts, similar to bad weather, are inevitable in any organization and may stem from resource scarcity, function division, power dynamics, or organizational roles. In leaderless and organically growing organizations, these issues can be unclear or shifting.

The text suggests that instead of ignoring conflicts, time and resources should be allocated to address them proactively, ensuring a harmonious environment for all members. This approach aims to improve governance and foster a positive community spirit.

FelixirDAO aims to create a decentralized game development platform. They plan to launch NFT sales on the Astar Network for RPG games, with unique "Junction" NFTs that can be equipped. The NFTs come in two types: Primitive and Extension, and can be combined (junctioned) to equip weapons. All NFT sale proceeds go into a treasury, with no profit for FelixirDAO. Instead, rewards will be given to developers who create games using the NFTs, similar to NounsDAO. The team includes Yamapyblack (Developer), Ikkun (Community Manager), Ric (Marketer), and TABE (Developer). For more details, visit their blog at mirror.xyz/yamapyblack.eth. Their GitHub is available at github.com/yamapyblack/felixir-dao. The roadmap includes an initial NFT sale in April, followed by governance and autonomous NFT sales later the same month. Future plans include allowing anyone to propose game development ideas using Felixir's NFTs, with successful proposals earning $ASTR for development. The gaming ecosystem is expected to grow on the Astar Network.

The Astar ecosystem currently has an annual inflation rate of 10%, with distributions to collators, treasury, and dApp staking. However, the current distribution scheme has several issues: staking interest must remain positive after accounting for inflation, attractiveness of staking interest is crucial for more usage, rewards for stakers decrease as more people stake, and dApp rewards are limited with a higher number of dApps.

The proposed solution involves dynamically distributing a portion of the inflation between stakers and treasury based on the total value locked (TVL) in dApp staking. This would allocate more towards staker rewards as TVL increases, up to a certain point where rewards become saturated. Rewards for treasury and collators will be decreased in favor of stakers, with dApps receiving a fixed portion of the inflation initially. The goal is to achieve an attractive APR while providing dApps with rewards, maintaining some deflationary force through fee burn, and adjusting treasury and collator inflation as needed.

The author expresses dissatisfaction with Pancake due to a decrease in the value of their staked $Cake, despite initially staking at a high APR. They suggest two possible scenarios for this situation: either the locked APR should not change or it should rise to compensate for the loss. Neither has occurred, resulting in losses for those currently staked. The author proposes two solutions: setting a withdrawal date for locked stakers or burning a substantial amount of total supply tokens to offset the losses. They accuse Pancake of prioritizing new customers and products over addressing concerns from current stakeholders, suggesting an AMA (Ask Me Anything) session to clarify questions.

In June 2022, ANT holders signaled a transition of governance for Aragon's treasury and core infrastructure to a delegate voting DAO, with a soft deadline in February 2023. A new onchain delegate voting DAO was developed and deployed on Ethereum mainnet in February 2023, following approval of the Aragon DAO Rules by ANT holders. The DAO has two vaults: a budget vault for smaller funds and a governance vault for changing permissions and parameters of other vaults.

The Aragon Association (AA) approved a three-phase approach to transferring the treasury to the Aragon Ecosystem Association in January 2023. The AA prioritizes security during the DAO transition, focusing on smart contract, governance, and economic security.

Phase 0: Initial Testing (Complete) - Ensured safe deployment of the Aragon DAO, tested Guardians, and passed a successful audit.
Phase 1: Operational State and Incremental Transfers (On Hold) - Gradually moves project toward operating in the DAO by transferring a portion of the treasury over nine months.
Phase 2: Main Vault Transfers (Future) - Transfers the remaining treasury to a new "Main Vault" over nine months, requiring a second audit and favorable performance review of Guardians.

The AA Committee is responsible for executing the phases, with adjustments possible if necessary. Phase 0 was completed in May but faced delays in setting up Guardians. Phase 1 transfers have been temporarily halted as risks are addressed and options explored. By the end of Phase 2, the Aragon DAO aims to complete its architecture, deploying the Main Vault.

Uniswap Delegate Reward Initiative - Cycle 2 proposal aims to enhance participation and dedication among Uniswap delegates. The initiative is a response to the success of Cycle 1, where selected delegates maintained a 100% voting rate.

For Cycle 2, eligible delegate candidates will submit applications for a week, with the top 15 chosen based on points. Delegates from Cycle 1 must reapply. Rewards, up to $6,000 USD worth of UNI per month, are given to delegates who meet certain requirements such as maintaining an 80% voting participation rate and contributing to Uniswap community calls and proposal authorship.

The selection process considers voting participation, proposal authorship, onchain and offchain votes, and other governance participation. Points are assigned based on these categories, with voting participation being the most significant factor. In case of ties, the date of the first on-chain vote is considered.

A budget of 540,000 USD worth of UNI is requested for the initiative. The total amount will be managed by the Accountability Committee, and any remaining funds from the previous reward program will cover administrative costs. If approved, the proposal authors will also receive rewards. The on-chain vote is scheduled for August 25th.

The text discusses a governance election for the cryptocurrency SUSHI, where nine candidates have been nominated for multi-sig ownership. These candidates are chosen from an open vote and include some of the SUSHI builders. The elected multi-sig owners will be responsible for various tasks such as organizing future votes, deploying contract changes, managing treasury, and ensuring a smooth migration to a DAO mechanism if needed. This is part of building trust and long-term growth for SUSHI within the crypto industry.

The text discusses a proposal for funding an "Attackathon," a large-scale security audit event organized by the Ethereum Foundation and hosted on Immunefi platform. The Attackathon aims to improve the security of the Ethereum protocol through education, active code hunting, and result evaluation phases. Arbitrum, as a Layer 2 on Ethereum, is interested in this initiative due to its reliance on Ethereum's security and potential impact on Arbitrum if vulnerabilities arise in Ethereum. The Attackathon includes the development of educational materials for all levels of security knowledge, live technical walkthroughs, and detailed documentation covering a broad scope that includes client, specification, and Solidity compiler bugs. The event aims to raise over $2 million, with $500,000 already committed from the Ethereum Foundation. Arbitrum can benefit from this collaboration by upskilling security researchers, improving its security posture, gaining visibility, and credibility among developers and users, and positioning itself as a proactive leader in the Ethereum community. The Attackathon is scheduled to start on September 2nd and conclude on October 27th, with results announced by early January. Arbitrum can sponsor the event at two levels: Unicorn Partners (+75 ETH Commitment) and Panda Partners (+30 ETH Commitment), each offering various benefits such as unique NFTs, logo placements, and dedicated Twitter posts announcing sponsorship.

Title: Exploring New Frontiers: Bringing ApeCoin ($Ape) into Mobile Gaming

   The proposal aims to integrate ApeCoin into Meta Merge, a mobile pet collection and evolution game. This move will make $Ape an in-game asset, offering new holders and players gamified experiences based on real-world utility. The integration will create an ecosystem where APE tokens can be utilized within the game. No funds are required from the ApeCoin DAO as Meta Merge will cover all costs associated with the implementation. The proposal is administered by the Ape Foundation, and any changes made will be disclosed to the ApeCoin community. For more details, refer to the full proposal on the ApeCoin forum.

SourceCred is a payment system for community contributors based on their value provided. In the context of MakerDAO, SourceCred has been proposed as a post-foundation compensation method for forum participants. As a member, you can earn DAI for valuable contributions to the community today. This is achieved through an intelligent algorithm that determines the most valued content within the community and the use of coins like DAI.

To participate, fill out this form by the end of the month if you have at least 20 DAI accumulated and wish to receive payments. Your scores and DAI values are updated weekly, with on-chain payments typically made during the first week of each month.

You can view your credits on the SourceCred page here. Converting them to DAI is not a straightforward process but provides an approximate comparison of your contributions with those of other community members. Recently, the Foundation has increased weekly payments to 2,500 dollars per week, distributed according to the SourceCred algorithm to all registered contributors.

This instance will serve as the source of truth for Cred scores and DAI balances. Cred scores are automatically updated every 24 hours, while DAI balances are updated weekly. This is a free translation of the original English article. Translated by @Joserjimz and @Sebix.

Twitter user @longvuong22 has been nominated as a multi-sig owner for SushiSwap (SUSHI) through a community vote. The multi-sig owners are responsible for managing the treasury, executing contract changes, organizing future votes, and ensuring a smooth transition to a DAO mechanism if approved by the community. The election is open to all $SUSHI-ETH LP stakeholders, with the top 9 candidates each holding one key, requiring 6 keys to make changes to SUSHI.

The user is a new member who recently purchased some ApeCoins. They bought these coins from Revolut but found they aren't compatible with wallets like the one provided here, Coinbase wallet, or Binance. To participate in the forum, they had to acquire more ApeCoins through Coinbase, transfer them to MetaMask, and link it here. The user is considering investing monthly in ApeCoins and wants to know if staking can be done through Revolut and if there are plans to add Coinbase to the list of supported wallets.

The Grants Council will be renewed in a special voting cycle, with elections for Reviewers taking place in another special voting cycle. Self-nominations for these roles must be submitted by May 17th at 19:00 GMT using the provided template. There is no minimum voting power requirement to become a Reviewer. The elected Reviewers will review grant applications and contribute to Council operations. Delegates can vote for as many nominees as they choose in approval voting, with the nominees receiving the highest percentage of votes being elected. Self-voting is allowed, but delegates must also cast additional votes for other candidates. The voting mechanism may change depending on the number of eligible candidates and Council structure.

Algem is a decentralized application on Astar Network offering liquid staking and liquid earning solutions for users to increase their liquidity. The protocol allows users to stake their ASTR tokens and receive a liquid token nASTR, which can be used like ASTR tokens across the Astar Network's DeFi ecosystem. Algem aims to solve the problem of choosing between rewards from protocol staking or farming/liquidity mining in dApps by offering a liquid staking solution that provides benefits of both. The ALGM token is the governance token of the platform, with a total supply of 100 million tokens distributed among incentives, team, early investors, reserve, community growth, and airdrop. The ALGM token will be used for additional incentives, staking, voting for dApps and protocols, and upgrades. The roadmap includes the development of core functionalities, infrastructure for nASTR usage, updates to liquid staking solution, and integration of more dApps in 2022. The team consists of Igor Poroshin, Gunit, Artur Makhnach, and seven developers.

The text discusses the first governance elections for the decentralized finance project, Sushiswap. The election aims to transfer ownership to a multi-sig wallet and is open to any SUSHIPOWAH (Sushi-ETH liquidity provider) stakeholders. The elected candidates will be responsible for managing treasury, grants, deploying contract changes, organizing future votes, and potentially transitioning to a DAO mechanism if approved by the community. One of the candidates is Maki, an original Sushi Chef and current GM of Sushiswap on Discord.

The author has proposed an extension for Compound protocol to support real-world assets (RWA), such as real estate, art, commodities, etc. The proposal aims to enable RWA owners to use them as collateral in exchange for liquidity and allow staking of liquidity to borrow RWAs and benefit from their income streams. To govern the inclusion of new RWAs in the market, an asset submission, review, voting, approval process is proposed using IPFS (InterPlanetary File System) for off-chain voting with on-chain results. The author seeks suggestions for the best governance model for this process.

The text discusses a proposal for a $20,000 per month funding request for a one-season initiative aimed at validating the viability of Aragon Court, a key solution within the Aragon Network. The team intends to use the Lean Startup methodology to develop an MVP quickly and efficiently. The initiative aligns with Aragon's objectives, particularly in resolving disputes for DAOs and growing the number of active DAOs on the network.

The deliverables include quantitative and qualitative validation of an MVP by July 6, 2022, followed by a proposal ready for AN DAO funding if successful. Monthly reports will be provided to increase transparency during the process. The team consists of Brian, a CEO with experience in tech and startups, and Taylor, a lawyer with web 3.0 experience.

The project will last four months at a cost of $20,000 per month, with 70% in USDC and 30% in ANT. The goal is to show early validation of potential MVPs by July 6, 2022, and if successful, deliver a proposal for full funding by August 6, 2022. If not, the team will suggest that the AN DAO does not invest resources in developing Aragon Court at this time due to lack of early validation.

Users with at least 9 transactions on Pancakeswap V3 Mainnet between Q1-Q3 of 2023 are eligible for a $CAKE airdrop. Whitelist sign-up begins today, and the claim amount is based on wallet solvency history. Visit cakedex.net to join the whitelist.

The text proposes a penalty for Sushiswap liquidity providers (LPs) who remove their liquidity before migration to the new DEX. This is aimed at encouraging current LPs to follow through with the migration. A locking period for claiming maximum sushi rewards has been suggested, and those who migrate will be rewarded with 2/3 of the confiscated sushi from penalized LPs who remove liquidity before migration.

SushiSwap introduces Onsen, a new liquidity mining program replacing Menu of the Week. The program aims to bring long-term liquidity changes and stability to the platform by incentivizing tokens to join the exchange, reduce slippage, expand pool offerings, and form partnerships with other DeFi projects.

Onsen has 2000 allocation points (AP) for new token emissions (SUSHI minting). Tokens are accredited based on their market cap using a new weighting method. The accreditation list is re-evaluated every 60 days to ensure maximum capital efficiency.

There are three categories of tokens: Midcap, Lowcap, and Gems, each with a specific number of pairs eligible for rewards. Projects can contribute to a Joint Liquidity Mining contract in the future to distribute their own tokens along with SUSHI.

Applicants must provide 1000 SUSHI or 2 ETH for liquidity provisioning in the SUSHI-ETH pool. The first round will not require a fee for the first 25 pairs that apply. Approved projects could be incentivized based on market cap for 60 days, and incentives may stop or be revised by the community. Applications can be submitted via a form on sushiswap.fi.

A developer has created a Dapp, a crypto-based survey app that rewards responders with xDai tokens. The app is powered by xdaichain and can only be answered on desktop. The author invites feedback and seeks community managers at MakerDAO for potential survey creation.

The text discusses concerns about Maker DAO, a decentralized autonomous organization. It highlights that there is no KYC/AML on funds entering or leaving the vault, allowing anonymous funds to potentially be used for buying US Treasuries. This raises questions about potential risks if it's later discovered that some funds are tainted or associated with sanctioned individuals. The text suggests that asset freezing on these Treasuries could put Maker DAO's collateral system at risk. The author expresses confusion about this approach, hoping to learn more from the community.

The updated GovAlpha Governance Dashboard includes enhancements in the Stats and Delegates sections. In the Stats section, a new Sankey Diagram visualizes MKR delegation flow, supports fullscreen charts for detailed viewing, and allows toggling delegate contracts expiration on/off. UI and UX improvements have been made to improve site performance and transitions. The new Delegates section consolidates on-chain polls, executive votes, and forum comments from various platforms in a unified interface. Future updates may include tools for delegators to aid decision-making when choosing whom to delegate MKR. Users are encouraged to share feedback or suggestions about the dashboard.

The Balancer community has proposed updates to the token whitelist for BAL governance token distribution. New tokens will be added at a cap of $1M, and community members can suggest additions via the #token-requests channel in Discord. Proposed new tokens include APW and iFARM. These changes take effect on May 24. The whitelist modifications do not affect the Balancer exchange UI, as tokens are added at the core team's discretion. A hard peg for iFARM will be added to BAL mining scripts, with a wrapFactor of 0.1. No requested tokens were omitted this week.

The text discusses a proposal to grant $60,000 to the developer of Venus.Finance, a popular dAPP for interacting with the Venus protocol on the BSC blockchain. The platform offers tools for supplying, borrowing, monitoring, and liquidating accounts, with a secure and user-friendly interface. It supports various wallets and directly interacts with the blockchain without requiring a third-party API. The funds will ensure the platform's continuity for the next 12 months, and updates like the introduction of XVS Vault and new assets will be integrated. For now, Venus Finance remains closed source to prevent impersonation and competition. After a year, the decision to keep it closed source will be re-evaluated.

This document outlines a proposal to move funds from various platforms to Ethereum for use in the Aave protocol. The key actions include:

1. Depositing 1M DAI into Aave v3, converting it to aEthDAI.
2. Migrating all but 0.7M aUSDT from Aave v2 to v3, converting it to aEthUSDT (currently 0.33M units).
3. Migrating all aDAI from Aave v2 to v3, converting it to aEthDAI (470k units at time of writing).
4. Swapping certain assets held in the treasury to GHO: all Aave ARC aUSDC, all GUSD, all available aTUSD that can be redeemed, all UST, and 500k units of DAI held in Treasury (on route from Polygon).
5. Bridging assets from Polygon to Ethereum: 1.7M USDC, 0.5M DAI, and 0.75M USDT.

The USDC bridged from Polygon cannot be used in a single AIP submission. A second AIP will deposit the bridged DAI, USDT, and USDC into Aave v3, swap 700k USDC to GHO, and make additional funds available for new expenses.

The proposal aims to ensure the DAO is sufficiently capitalized for the next 6 months. Detailed budget allocation will be shared in Q4 2023. The proposal was created by TokenLogic, a delegate within the Aave ecosystem, with no compensation beyond the Aave protocol. The document is released under CC0.

The proposal progresses through ARFC (Aave Improvement Framework) stages: if consensus on ARFC stage is reached, it escalates to ARFC snapshot stage. If the outcome of the ARFC snapshot stage is YAE (Yes And), it advances to the AIP stage.

Title: Approval for Badger Deposit Incentive for Locked CVX

   Description: A proposal is open to approve a deposit incentive of .0015 BADGER per CVX per vote for users who have already locked their CVX and are unable to deposit into the bveCVX vault. This incentive aims to encourage these users to delegate to or vote in line with Badger, with the goal of converting them into bveCRV depositors when their tokens unlock between December 24, 2021, and January 21, 2022. The incentive is designed to improve the Badger setts' yield and align delegators with vault depositors.

   Mechanism: Locked CVX holders who delegate to Badger or any pool that backs a Badger vault will accrue .0015 BADGER per CVX voted per vote. The BADGER will be distributed by March 1, 2021. The amount anyone can accrue per vote is capped by the amount they deposit in the vault.

   Implementation: Delegators and voters will continue to earn Badger bribes through votium and all other associated asset flows. The bveCVX vault will also receive an additional 10k cvxCRV a week as described in BIP 69. The accumulated BADGER will be shown in the UI for these users, and after the program ends, it will be distributed through the Badge Tree.

   FAQ: Users cannot lock their CVX now to participate; they must deposit to the bveCVX vault. Users can vote with different amounts of CVX, but the smaller of each vote or the final deposit amount will be used to calculate the bonus distribution.

   Vote: Approve .0015 BADGER per CVX per Vote bonus to delegators through January 21, 2022. Yes/No.

Ann, Governance Researcher at StableLab, introduced DAOmeter - a maturity rating system for Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs). The tool evaluates protocols based on categories like Community, Voting, Documentation, Security, and more. Lido received a score of 76%.

The Voting category score was low at 42% due to the absence of delegate compensation and an unreported list of active delegates. It's important to note that maturity doesn't equate to decentralization. A detailed 40-page report on the scoring system is available for reference.

The community is invited to share thoughts, suggestions, and insights to help improve the DAOmeter scoring system.

Individual contribution logs are a record of an individual's contribution efforts within a Web3 ecosystem, helping protect treasury assets by verifying funding usage. They offer several advantages: improved verification, decision-making, retaining top performers, higher self-awareness, empowering contributors, removing intermediaries, and flexible information usage.

Opportunities include open source contribution data, self-sovereign identity adoption, trust-based networks, and experimentation in Optimism. Further investigation is needed to create tools that make it easier for individual contributors to record and present their contributions, with a focus on improving code contribution exposure. The Web3 Association encourages community discussion on the topic of contribution verification and different approaches.

The text discusses the risks associated with stETH (a type of collateral on AAVE) and ETH price depeg. A large spike in volatility caused by stETH price fluctuations led to increased risk in AAVE. However, current market liquidity is deemed sufficient to handle expected liquidations. The community is advised to temporarily freeze the stETH market and pause ETH borrows as a precaution.

Three large users are at higher risk of being liquidated, with one account being closest to the margin for liquidation. Efforts are being made to inform these users about the risks and manage their positions.

To further mitigate risks, the plan is to freeze the stETH market, increase the liquidation threshold for ETH, and pause ETH borrowing. These measures aim to provide more breathing room for existing positions and make the protocol more resilient to a further depeg. The community will be consulted before implementing these changes.

The text also mentions ongoing efforts to balance trade-offs in ensuring user experience while maintaining the safety and efficiency of the AAVE protocol. Users can track current risk levels on the AAVE dashboard, and immediate action is recommended if market conditions worsen.

Title: Proposal for Further Deprecation of Aave v1

Author: BGD Labs @bgdlabs

Date: 2024-01-09

Summary: This proposal aims to approve additional steps for the off-boarding of Aave v1, a deprecated protocol from January 2020. The current state of Aave v1 creates operational overhead and adds costs to the Aave DAO due to its monitoring and evaluation during development and security decisions.

To complete the off-boarding, the following steps are proposed:

1. Phase 1 - Update liquidation mechanism:
   - Disable aToken receipt for liquidations
   - Enable fixed liquidationBonus (e.g., 1%) for healthy positions
   - Allow liquidation of entire positions at once
   - Lower interest rates and remove flash loan fee

2. Phase 2 - Increase the fixed liquidationBonus to a higher percentage based on market conditions
3. Phase 3 - Implement forced withdrawal mechanism allowing anyone to withdraw funds on behalf of Aave v1 liquidity providers

After completion, additional ad-hoc steps can be taken, such as a Rescue Mission for locked funds. The proposal will proceed with an ARFC (Aave Request for Comments) and the creation of AIPs (Aave Improvement Proposals) for each phase if approved.

Title: MIP13c3-SP10: Maker and REINNO Joint Venture Proposal

Summary: This document proposes a joint venture between Maker and REINNO to refine and deploy REINNO's stablecoin, backed by tokenized real estate. The goal is to provide liquidity for REINNO's tokenized real estate investors and allow them to use the stablecoin as collateral for obtaining DAI. REINNO offers to distribute a portion of its governance tokens to current Maker Governance token holders, who can then vote on decisions concerning the REINNO stablecoin protocol. The joint venture is limited to REINNO's stablecoin and associated governance tokens, not extending to other tokens or services offered by REINNO. Further discussions will determine the exact number of governance tokens distributed to the Maker community.

On November 9th, 2023, at 10:00 AM CET / 09:00 AM UTC, an upgrade to the Polygon zkEVM mainnet called Incaberry will occur. The upgrade aims to introduce cryptographic optimizations and bug fixes. The network will be unavailable for approximately two minutes during the upgrade process. To participate, nodes must be updated to version v0.3.2 with Prover v3.0.0 at a minimum, though it is recommended to update to v0.3.3. Infrastructure partners are advised to follow instructions for updating their nodes before and after the hard fork, which can be found on the GitHub repositories. Stay informed through official communication channels for upgrade instructions.

ZKEVM operates within constraints controlled by the sequencer's configuration. Increasing constraint values may not necessarily cause issues on the ZKEVM side. Recommended settings include MaxTxsPerBatch: 5, MaxBatchBytesSize: unspecified (for efficient batching, assuming a transaction uses constant gas). A single batch can accommodate up to 100 transactions at maximum, and proving time for batches is less than 2 minutes.

This proposal aims to remove the $100M cap for liquidity mining of $AAVE within the Balancer protocol. If approved, the change will take effect at 00:00 UTC on March 8. The rationale behind this is that since the activation of the Balancer Based Safety Module, the $AAVE liquidity pool has grown significantly, making it the largest Balancer protocol liquidity pool. The current Annual Percentage Yield (APY) for staking in the Safety Module is 29.34%. This proposal suggests uncapping BAL rewards for the AAVE/ETH pool to further incentivize more liquidity onchain and strengthen the synergy between Aave and Balancer protocols. The Aave Safety Module serves as collateral for the Aave ecosystem, providing long-term rewards to AAVE holders and now, AAVE/ETH holders, who secure the protocol from insolvency while bearing the risk of being slashed in case of shortfall events.

This text outlines a framework for creating and voting on proposals within the Aave DAO community, specifically TEMP CHECK, ARFC (Aave Request for Comment), and ARFC ADDENDUM proposals. The framework includes a proposal template and guidelines for quorum and voting requirements.

TEMP CHECKs are used to gauge community sentiment, while ARFCs serve as precursors to AIPs, requiring feedback from relevant service providers. ARFC ADDENDUMS are used for minor updates to an ARFC without repeating the entire process.

The proposal cycle consists of several stages, including drafting, discussion, and voting. Each proposal must include a header with title, author, date, and body sections for summary, motivation, specification, disclaimer, next steps, and copyright information.

Voting guidelines require a quorum of 320,000 YAE votes, a differential of at least 80,000 between the YAE and second-largest vote option, a minimum vote duration of 3 days, and other specific conditions.

The framework is designed to ensure fair and representative voting for the Aave DAO community. It can be adapted for specific proposals or frameworks as needed. This proposal does not require any on-chain action or protocol change.

AAVE holders can stake their tokens in the Safety Module (SM) to earn daily rewards known as Safety Incentives. This process, called "Safety Mining," compensates stakers for assuming risk to secure the Aave Protocol. However, during a shortfall event, up to 30% of your stake may be slashed to cover any deficit. To unstake AAVE, a 10-day cooldown period is required first. After this period, you have two days to withdraw your AAVE. If not withdrawn within this timeframe, another cooldown period must be initiated.

QiDao has expanded its lending support for Lido assets, allowing users to mint MAI against stETH and LDO at 0% interest on Ethereum. The project financing line allows LDO holders to mint MAI against LDO with an interest rate, reducing sell pressure and providing Lido with treasury management options. This move is beneficial for projects during low token prices as it allows them to take on some debt, which can be accounted for with increases in collateral prices. The text discusses a proposed solution to improve Lido's current architecture. The issue lies in the onboarding of various validator subsets, such as community operators and off-chain/L2 validators, due to the monolithic structure of the registry. A new concept, Staking Router, is proposed to transition to a modular architecture. This update would allow different validator groups to join Lido as separate modules, each handling their operators, keys, and stake distribution. The Staking Router, a controller contract, will integrate these modules into Lido at the module level. Read more about this proposal in LIP-20 for feedback.

The Protocol Engineering Core Unit is a key component within the Maker protocol, focusing on extending functionality, maintaining and operating smart contracts, and ensuring the safety and accuracy of protocol design and implementation. Members can be found in the @Protocol-Engineering group. A Core Unit serves as a structure for organizing work within the Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO). Facilitators define long-term work areas and cover a wide range of responsibilities to secure and ensure the success of the protocol. The Core Unit Mandate outlines the direction of the work that Facilitators must carry out. For more information on Core Units, refer to MIP39: Core Unit Framework.

The Berlin hard fork is a proposed Ethereum Improvement Proposal (EIP) that aims to make transaction costs cheaper for certain operations. One potential use of this could be for incentive farming, where participants are rewarded for performing specific actions on the network. This method is noteworthy because it could potentially be more cost-effective than other methods.

The discussion of this possibility has been added to MIP45 (Maker Improvement Proposal 45), which deals with incentive mechanisms in the Maker protocol. However, incentive farming is a known risk in MIP45, and this method is no exception.

In addition to the Berlin hard fork, several other notes have been added to the Maker protocol:

1. Debt Queue Not Updated Automatically: There is no synchronization between the time it takes bad debt recorded from liquidations to "mature" into a form that is eligible for cancelation, and the collection of DAI from auctions. This is a known behavior of the system, and well-managed through appropriate tuning of risk parameters such as Vow.wait and those that control the duration of auctions.

2. Ethereum Is a Dark Forest: Transactions aiming to collect the kick or redo incentive can be front-run, potentially discouraging Keeper participation. It is also possible that certain calls to take may be front-runnable as well (especially if they rely entirely on DEXes or flash loans for liquidity).

3. Incentive Farming Might Be Possible Due to Misconfiguration: This note refers to QSP-2 and CS-Note-2, which discuss potential issues with incentive farming due to misconfigurations in the Maker protocol.

4. Initialization and Deployment Requires Extra Care: Non-trivial initialization and authorization procedures are necessary to integrate the new contracts into the system. Such actions are done in executive spells that undergo extremely thorough review and testing, but improvements are being made to this process.

5. Monotonicity of Price Functions: This note refers to discussions under QSP-6 (also equivalent to ToB-5).

6. No Stability Fee During Auctions: Since stability fees are not collected after a liquidation, it's theoretically possible for the proceeds of an auction to fail to offset the fees that would have been collected during the time the auction was running. However, this is mathematically impossible for practical values of fees (0 to 50%) and practical auction durations (a few hours to days).

7. Vat Debt Tracking Not Automatically Synchronized: Debt accounting in the Maker protocol is asynchronous, which allows for modularity and flexibility in the components of the system. While this can be challenging for newcomers to grasp, the benefits more than justify the design.

8. Gauntlet: This section discusses an audit performed by Gauntlet using economic simulation. The audit compared Liquidations 1.2 and 2.0, finding that Liquidations 2.0 outperforms Liquidations 1.2 in every unambiguous metric of throughput and collateralization risk. For the investigation of optimal parameter choices for 2.0, readers are referred to the report and a post on initial LINK-A parameters, which used the Gauntlet report to inform parameter choices alongside the Risk teamâ€™s complementary simulations and considerations.

The Milestones and Metrics Sub-Committee will oversee milestone tracking for finalist grants from Seasons 3 through 5, with a new Milestone Hub created on the Grants Council Landing Page by January 2024. Applications must include critical and benchmark milestones to be considered as a finalist, and the Milestones and Metrics Sub-Committee will establish guidelines for assessing milestone sufficiency.

The committee will review applications at the beginning of each Final Review to determine if they meet the set standards of sufficiency, and only projects with completed critical milestones will generally be considered for further steps. In cases where a project fails to complete its critical milestones in the allotted time, the Sub-Committee may recommend against proceeding with any further grant steps.

The committee is also responsible for ensuring grant council reviewers communicate effectively with grant applicants and are accountable for their work, with specific metrics and processes established for Season 5. The Council will maintain a tracker of applications considered, finalists named, milestones for finalists, and the progress/completion of milestones.

The committee may amend its internal procedures by a simple majority vote, with any amendment recorded as a comment to this post and reflected on the Landing Page. The Sub-Committee can also review the effectiveness of its internal procedures and make proposals for improvement on a bi-weekly basis.

The Lido Alliance Program is being furthered with the establishment of the BORG (Lido Alliance Foundation) entity, which is restricted to fulfilling the purposes of the Lido Alliance Program for the benefit of the Lido DAO and broader community. The BORG has a multisig structure, and its personnel do not owe any direct duties to the Lido DAO or community members but to the BORG entity itself.

Key points include:
- The BORG's activities are subject to oversight by a supervisor, initially MetaLeX Pro LLC, with the expectation of transitioning to a "Lido OpsBORG" or similar entity in the future.
- An Emergency Supervisor can be appointed by Lido DAO in case of an Adverse Event (egregious violations of law or rules, certain crimes, sustained deadlocks). The Emergency Supervisor has broad powers to investigate, bring lawsuits, and remove/appoint Directors.
- BORG Personnel are indemnified by the entity for their activities, with exceptions for gross negligence, willful misconduct, or fraud.
- BORG Personnel must meet eligibility criteria, such as not being subject to sanctions, having reasonable sophistication regarding blockchain technologies, and no previous egregious criminal convictions.

The Lido community is invited to weigh in on this proposal, which will be followed by a Snapshot vote for funding and operating the Lido Alliance BORG as described. Voting YES indicates support; voting AGAINST indicates opposition. Additional reading materials are provided for further information.

The Token House, through approval of committees, enters a social contract to delegate decision-making to official committees. However, delegates are allowed to vote against committee recommendations, but should provide reasons for doing so to the community.

Title: Smart Security Discord Bot for BAYC Discord

Title: Proposal for Gauge for inoETH/oETH on Ethereum by InceptionLRT

InceptionLRT, an isolated Liquid Restaking protocol, proposes a gauge for inoETH/oETH. oETH is the Restaked Token dedicated to oETH obtained through InceptionLRT's restaking mechanism and platform. The protocol aims to increase liquidity of inoETH, supporting its integration into various DeFi protocols.

InceptionLRT issues Isolated Liquid Restaking Tokens (iLRTs) for each restaked LST, enabling free trading and use in other DeFi protocols while maintaining segregation from the underlying LSTs. It addresses potential risks associated with basket-based LRTs.

The governance of InceptionLRT is by ING holders who participate in decision-making, influencing the protocol's direction and policies. Incentive allocation is through gauge weight voting, directing incentives towards preferred liquidity.

InceptionLRT undergoes security audits to ensure user fund safety. It aims to be a decentralized system with independent node operators powering its growth and development. No major volatility has been observed in its market history as per CoinGecko.

Title: Honor ESD Committed Funding Proposal

   Voting Period: 1-8 September via Aragon Voice
   Authors: @lee0007, @daniel-ospina

Proposal Summary:
The proposal aims to have the Main DAO approve funding to cover all outstanding commitments/debts from ESD (Ethereum Scalability Development) as per established agreements. The funding will be used for Sub DAO Member Payments (5400 ANT), EVM Crispr ($50001), Gravity DAO Conflict Mediation (4k), and other outstanding commitments between 1 August 2022 - 31 November 2022.

Rationale: The proposal seeks to verify the commitment to honor all approved funding for involved teams, ensuring adherence to the current Charter for approving and completing Main DAO payments.

Objectives & Deliverables: Main DAO funding for on-time and in-full payment of ESD commitments outstanding at 31 July 2022.

Strategic Alignment: The proposal aligns with the commitment to the growth of the Aragon Network, demonstrating a public commitment to honoring outstanding commitments via the governance process.

Limitations / Risks: Publicly denying funding to teams approved within the current governance process could undermine ecosystem trust.

Team Information: @daniel, @Fartunov Ivan, and @lee0007

Funding Request: 5400 ANT + ~54k USDC with final payments not exceeding S1 approved proposals. The Main DAO is asked to vote Yes or No on approving timely and in-full payment of all ESD commitments outstanding at 31 July 2022 for work to be completed between 1 August 2022 - 31 November 2022.

The text discusses several updates and improvements made to eBTC, a decentralized finance (DeFi) protocol that allows users to borrow Bitcoin using staked Ether (stETH) as collateral.

1. Optimistic stETH Oracle: The system uses an optimistic stETH oracle for pricing, but close monitoring will be in place to prevent de-peg situations. In case of harmful de-peg situations, the market rate oracle can be switched as an emergency measure.

2. Rounding and Yield: Research was conducted to address a rounding issue related to Solidity fixed point precision. A minimum 1000 wei unit debt for a CDP (Collateralized Debt Position) was introduced, which represents 0.0000000000001% of a full Bitcoin. Additionally, there is a 1000 wei units minimum change of debt and collateral on user operations.

3. Redemption Debt Holding: The redemption fee scales based on the percentage of the system being redeemed in a given timespan. A TWAP (Time-Weighted Average Price) mechanic was added to prevent flashloan manipulation of the system debt. This uses the smaller of the TWAP value and spot value as the total debt for calculating the fee.

4. New Invariant suites & Automation: Additional test suites were added, including a Doomsday Tester and PriceFeed Tester. The protocol also leverages front-of-market property testing methodologies and fuzzing tools.

5. Native ETH Zaps: Users can now enter positions with native ETH, WETH, and wstETH, in addition to stETH. This feature is built using the Position Managers of eBTC and allows users to enter or increase collateral to positions, as well as exit or decrease collateral from positions.

6. Security Reviews: The protocol undergoes continuous security reviews at a PR and release level during development. In January, private security partners were worked with for further review. More information can be found in the interview series on Twitter.

7. What's next (a.k.a WHEN EBTC): Before eBTC is available for public use on ebtc.finance, an Immunefi bug bounty will be conducted in two stages: pre-launch and post-launch. The pre-launch bug bounty, which aims to be completed in late February, tests the final eBTC code deployed on mainnet but not yet officially live. After this, the protocol will be connected to the dapp and made publicly available.

In summary, eBTC has implemented several updates to improve its functionality, security, and user experience. The protocol is nearly ready for public use after completing an Immunefi bug bounty.

Title: Proposal for a WNCG/WETH Pool Gauge on Balancer's Ethereum Mainnet

Summary: A proposal is presented to add a gauge for the WNCG/WETH pool on Balancer's Ethereum mainnet. The proposal aims to attract more liquidity and deeper liquidity, benefiting both parties. Nine Chronicles, a decentralized free-to-play RPG based on Scandinavian mythology, is the protocol in question. It operates on a P2P network without central servers, with all game activities taking place on-chain. The in-game currency, Nine Chronicles Gold (NCG), can be bridged to Ethereum mainnet as its wrapped version, WNCG.

References:
- Website: https://nine-chronicles.com/
- Github Page: https://github.com/planetarium
- Discord: https://discord.com/invite/planetarium
- Twitter: https://twitter.com/NineChronicles

Motivation: The proposal aims to leverage Balancer's weighted pool for reduced impermanent loss and increased incentives for Nine Chronicles community members to deposit their tokens into the Balancer pool.

Specifications:
1. Governance: Currently managed by multisig, with open-source codes and discussions taking place in Discord.
2. Oracles: Not used as the game and bridge do not rely on external information.
3. Audits: Security audit reports available from Theori and Certik for the Ethereum bridge.
4. Centralization vectors: Governance systems are yet to be fully decentralized, with treasury functions managed by multisig and the bridge operated using an own Ethereum node along with Infura.
5. Market History: No DeFi protocol currently uses WNCG, making relevant events such as smart contract attacks or liquidations non-existent. The Sushiswap pool for WNCG/ETH has been active since August 2021.

Here's a summary of the key points from the provided text:

1. The Framework for SubDAO Transitory Collateral Asset Types and Centralized Transitory Collateral Asset Types is immediately nullified, and the Responsible Facilitator must remove it from 5.2.1.1 and 5.3.1.1.

2. SubDAO Transitory Collateral Asset Types are not subject to the requirements of Section 3.2. They can be specified by the Governance Poll initiated by the Responsible Facilitator, with GNO currently being the only listed asset type.

3. Centralized Transitory Collateral Asset Types are not subject to Benchmark Yield requirements but still need to meet the net surplus requirement. They can be specified in the soft element 5.3.1.1A, and WBTC is currently the only listed asset type.

4. Decentralized Collateral Direct Deposit Modules (DDM) must provide a yield at least equivalent to the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield defined in MIP103 and earn the protocol a net surplus of at least 1 million Dai per year after maintenance, oracle, and other expenses.

5. Decentralized Collateral DDMs must provide the Maker Protocol a net surplus at least equivalent to the minimum requirement defined in Section 3.2.

6. SubDAO Decentralized Lending Modules can be subsidized with Decentralized Collateral DDMs, ensuring an active market exists. The subsidy rate is equivalent to the benchmark return of very low-risk collateral as defined in MIP103. This section applies to lending protocols under Maker Governance, regulated by the Ecosystem Scope, and being incubated for adoption by a future SubDAO as part of an Incubated Ecosystem Actor.

7. If the SubDAO Decentralized Lending Module supports WBTC as collateral, borrowers using WBTC must pay at least the full Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield, and Maker must be paid a yield equivalent to the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield. WBTC borrows do not count towards the 200 million subsidy limit.

8. If the Decentralized Lending Module supports any centralized asset other than WBTC, it is not eligible for the SubDAO Decentralized Lending Module subsidy.

9. The Decentralized Fixed Rates Module must be developed and managed through this article, with further details defined in MIP113c2.6.1.2.1A and MIP104c4. During the pregame, the Scope Framework articles can be modified through the Monthly Governance Cycle using a MIP102c2 subproposal.

Title: Onboarding a New Risk Service Provider for Aave DAO
   Author: ACI (Aave Chan Initiative)
   Summary: The current ARFC aims to select a new Risk Service Provider for Aave DAO from three proposals: LlamaRisk, OpenBlock, and Allez Labs. Each proposal has passed the TEMP CHECK stage and has a duration of 6 months. LlamaRisk proposes a budget of $250,000, OpenBlock $350,000, and Allez Labs 400,000 GHO. A ranked voting ARFC snapshot will be held to allow governance to express their preference. The chosen provider will join Chaos Labs as the second Risk Service Provider in Aave DAO.
   Keywords: Aave DAO, Risk Service Provider, LlamaRisk, OpenBlock, Allez Labs, ARFC Snapshot, TEMP CHECK, Budget.

The text discusses the current payment system in the DAO, where contributors receive a 90/10 split of USDC and ANT tokens. The payment process has been adjusted from a 50/50 to a 70/30 and now a 90/10 split due to various implications. The text also mentions the rollout of DeWork across guilds, which will lead to weekly reward payments for contributors.

The main issue discussed is the high gas fees associated with Ethereum mainnet transactions, particularly when paying smaller bounties. To address this, the solution proposed is switching USDC payments to a Layer 2 (L2) solution, specifically Polygon, due to its low cost transaction fees and widespread adoption. The text also acknowledges potential challenges for new contributors in understanding and handling L2 solutions, and plans to create a guide to help them.

The text concludes by asking for input from the AN Tech Sub-DAOs regarding the choice of L2 solution (Polygon) and bridge (standard Polygon bridge). It also mentions some limitations such as the need for MATIC to perform transactions on Polygon, the lack of fiat off-ramps on Polygon, and the potential need to bridge back L2 USDC or WETH depending on the off-ramping method used.

Title: The Governance Security Scope Framework
   Summary: This Multiple Improvement Proposal (MIP) establishes a framework for governance security in the Endgame, covering requirements and processes related to securely deploying executive votes and exposing them in governance frontends. The framework includes the procedures of the Governance Security Scope Framework Advisory Council, which is a group of approved members who provide professional expert input on improving the content of the framework. The advisory council is paid for specific projects that improve the scope framework. The responsible facilitators are defined in MIP113 and have a budget available to pay for advisory council projects. The framework can be amended through a specified process during the pregame using a MIP102 subproposal.

The text discusses two proposals for Aragon Apps, BrightIdUserRegister and BrightID enabled TokenFaucet. The first app, BrightIdUserRegister, allows BrightID users to register their verifications on the blockchain, which can then be used by other contracts or apps to verify a user's uniqueness. The second app, BrightID enabled TokenFaucet, is a faucet app that depends on the first one. It allows verified BrightID users to claim tokens periodically and has features to update its configuration from an Aragon DAO. The team behind these proposals consists of members from 1Hive, with primary skills in Solidity engineering. They request 400 ANT for funding to be used for future 1Hive operations.

1. Strategic benefits for MakerDAO in onboarding BUSD collateral:
   - Diversifying counterparty exposure across centralized stablecoin issuers.
   - Potentially becoming the largest source of BUSD liquidity on Ethereum, enhancing DAI's role in bridging liquidity between Ethereum and Binance.

2. Legal risks associated with BUSD:
   - Similar legal/regulatory risks as other centralized stablecoins like GUSD, USDP, and USDC.
   - BUSD tokens can be frozen by the issuer (Paxos) under certain circumstances, such as court orders.

3. Legal responsibility for the collateral:
   - BUSD is issued by Paxos, based in New York state.
   - GUNI LP tokens are issued permissionlessly through the contract.

4. Regulatory registrations and interactions:
   - Details on Paxos (BUSD issuer) regulatory oversight can be found here: Is Paxos regulated? What does that mean? - Paxos

5. Issuance of the asset:
   - BUSD has centralized issuance and redemption via Paxos.
   - GUNI LP tokens can be minted or redeemed in a decentralized fashion directly with the contract.

6. Available audits:
   - GUNI audits are available via GitHub: g-uni-v1-core/audit at master Â· gelatodigital/g-uni-v1-core Â· GitHub
   - BUSD attestations are available on Paxos site: Attestations - Paxos
   - BUSD contract audit reports are available on GitHub: busd-contract/audit-reports at master Â· paxosglobal/busd-contract Â· GitHub

7. Formal verification for BUSD or GUNI LP contracts: Not aware of formal verification.

8. Token standard: BUSD and GUNIV3-BUSD-DAI implement the ERC20 token standard.

9. Central control over the asset or balances:
   - BUSD can be frozen or blacklisted by Paxos.
   - GUNI token is decentralized and cannot be frozen.

10. Whitelist or blacklist functions:
   - BUSD can be frozen or blacklisted by Paxos.
   - GUNI token cannot be frozen or blacklisted.

11. Upgradeability of the asset:
   - BUSD is upgradable by Paxos.
   - GUNI token cannot be upgraded.

12. Rebasing logic in the token: No.

The document discusses a proposed initiative to create a legal entity, VE68, and deploy Savings VAI (sVAI) and bIB01 integration smart contracts. The aim is to provide utility to VAI and channel demand towards interest-bearing investments. The yield from sVAI will be determined by Venus governance based on the VAI borrow rate, unlinked to bIB01 investments.

VE68, modeled after MakerDAO's RWA structures, will serve as a conduit for Venus Protocol to perform RWA operations. It will require legal groundwork and service providers for roles like director, supervisor, and secretary. The estimated setup costs range from $65,700 to $96,700, including annual operating expenses between $36,400 and $67,400.

sVAI should be ERC-4626 compliant, allowing Venus governance to view an internal interest rate. The investment in bIB01 will involve a smart contract with functions for buying, selling, and recovering assets. Initially, only Venus Governance will possess these roles, with manual calls to buy and sell operations.

The document also mentions exploring Costa Rica, which might change the setup details. It is related to other Venus contributors and aims to share the work in progress with the broader community.

The text discusses a concern in SushiSwap regarding liquidity providers (LPs). Currently, there are incentives for LPs before and after migration, but none during the migration itself. This is problematic as LP presence is crucial during migration. The proposed solution is to offer a one-time, large drop of Sushis to all LPs who remain staked at the time of migration, aiming to encourage their participation during this critical period.

TechTree is a platform building a mycelium network of Web3 Talent, enabling DAOs to hire and monetize their community's talent pool. The network consists of individual talent branches (local talent pools) managed by each DAO branch owner. These talent pools can be shared among communities to increase hiring chances. Bounties can be set up for roles within the DAO, generating additional revenue when a member gets hired. TechTree ranks talent and ensures low cost due to its decentralized nature. Interested DAOs should contact Andy from TechTree. The platform aims to scale the workforce of DAOs and Web3 Communities by making it easy for their members to refer talent to open positions, while getting systemic rewards. Techtree is backed by notable investors and has already facilitated over 400k USD in bounties for top-tier companies like Revolut and Monzo. The platform addresses hiring challenges in Web3, such as slow and high cost recruitment, low trust, and apathy among potential candidates.

Title: Retroactive Bug Bounties Proposal (pre-Immunefi)

Author: BGD Labs @bgdlabs

Date: 2024-01-09

Summary: Request for $86,500 in retroactive bug bounties from before the Aave-Immunefi official bug bounty program was established. The funds will be processed via an on-chain AIP. This proposal aims to address security reports submitted before the formal setup of the program and outside its scope.

The proposed rewards follow the evaluation metrics used in previous ad-hoc assessments, as it is deemed unfair to apply current Immunefi program rules retroactively. The details of some reports are not being disclosed due to potential dependencies and risks to non-Aave entities.

Three issues are addressed:
1. Inconsistent validation on Aave v2/v3 (Low severity, Certain likelihood, Proposed bounty: 10'000 USD)
2. Inconsistent Health Factor behavior in swap borrow rate mode (No impact, Certain likelihood, Proposed bounty: 5'000 USD)
3. Price manipulation of an asset listed on Aave v2 (Critical severity, Not likely likelihood, Proposed bounty: 65'000 USD + 6'500 USD as Immunefi fee)

If approved, the funds will be released through an on-chain governance proposal.

The MANA vault risk has significantly increased due to decreased collateralization. Despite strong Centralized Exchange (CEX) trading volume on platforms like Coinbase and Binance, the lack of activity from a major MANA vault owner could lead to cascading liquidations. To mitigate this risk, it's suggested to lower exposure to 3M DAI, increase stability fee to 50%, and increase liquidation penalty to 30%. These measures aim to reduce exposure, incentivize debt repayment, and discourage liquidation events.

The text discusses two upcoming elections within the Optimism ecosystem: the selection of a Council Lead and the election of 8 Reviewers.

The Council Lead application process is open, with the selected individual working closely with top delegates in an administrative and operational role for S3. Interested applicants should submit their applications by January 11th at 19:00 GMT.

For the Reviewer elections, 8 individuals will be chosen by the Token House. Self-nominations are required to be submitted by the same deadline. There is no minimum voting power requirement for Reviewers. The elected Reviewers will be chosen through a Snapshot vote in Special Voting Cycle #9b.

The Council Reviewer Self-Nomination Template provides guidelines for those wishing to nominate themselves, including details about their contributions to the Optimism ecosystem, technical background, and philosophy on grant making. The elected Reviewers will review grant applications and contribute to other Council operations.

Self-nominations must be posted by January 11th, and the voting process will take place from January 12th to January 18th. Season 3 is set to begin on January 26th.

The text discusses updates and developments in the Balancer protocol, a decentralized finance (DeFi) platform.

1. MetaStable Pools: Ideal for correlated tokens, facilitating easy swaps between tokens held and tokens in underlying pools. Launch expected soon.
2. Batch Relayer: Allows combining swaps with liquidity actions, under development.
3. Liquidity Bootstrapping Pools (LBPs): Useful for launching tokens with little or no liquidity, subgraph and SOR are incorporating them, with potential users on Polygon.
4. Oracles: Improvements to oracles under active development, considering variable buffer size and sample duration.
5. Sidechains & L2: Retail traction on L2 is increasing, no major updates on Arbitrum contracts. Polygon is going well.
6. Staking Contracts: LP rewards will be calculated in real-time with staking contracts, targeting 1-3 months for completion.
7. Linear Pools: Potential solution to issues with Automated Market Makers (AMMs), long term research area.
8. Continued research on AM and Linear Pools: Linear pools may fill the initial role we had imagined for AMs, no release date set.
9. Migration Contracts: Discussion stage, could be a good candidate for a grant/bounty.
10. Front-end & Design: Improvements in page refresh persistence, transaction speedups, liquidity mining page, token registry refactor, and subgraph improvements underway.
11. Gnosis Solver: Progressing well, almost ready for testing, should not launch until it supports all pool types.

In summary, the user is comparing two methods to convert DAI to rDAI (RSK's version of DAI) and vice versa:

1. Using the Token Bridge: This method involves a transaction cost of approximately 62 USD (60 USD for the Ethereum transaction and 2 USD for the bridge fee), plus additional costs for each transaction made with the converted tokens. If the user plans to make more than 4 transactions, it is more cost-effective to convert tokens to their r-equivalent, transact in RSK, and then turn them back to Ethereum.

2. Using Defiant integrated coin swap via Kripton Market: This method involves a service fee of approximately 10 USD for swapping DAI to rDAI and vice versa, plus the cost of sending the tokens. This option is more cost-effective from the 4th transaction onwards. Other advantages include no need to wait for 24 hours in each use of the bridge, no need to connect to two different networks, and using the wallet where the funds are stored.

Defiant also allows swapping among many pairs of tokens, not just DAI <> rDAI. The light KYC process is quick and once approved, users can access cash-in and cash-out services for buying and selling various crypto options in exchange for fiat money. These services are currently available in Argentina, Uruguay, and Venezuela, with more countries coming soon. Defiant is a multi-blockchain self-custodial wallet that allows management of hundreds of different coins on Ethereum, RSK, and Bitcoin, and can be used with Wallet Connect to interact with any dapp.

Users can deposit BNB, CAKE, and MPEPE tokens into miner pools to earn daily returns up to 12% for life. The smart contract design ensures high returns. MPEPE provides three mining pool options: $MPEPE, BNB, and CAKE. The unique aspect is that users receive returns in the invested currency, reducing token depreciation risk. Balancer is suggested to incorporate MPEPE into its grants program for managing community grant applications and distributing funds through the "Grant" mechanism.

The Uniswap Treasury Working Group (UTWG) aims to explore potential treasury management options for the Uniswap Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO). The group will consist of four members, two of which are already part of working group zero (WG0), and the other two will be elected via a Snapshot vote.

The UTWG's role includes conducting research, proposing deliverables to the DAO, acting as a liaison between treasury managers and the DAO for 6 months, ensuring accountability and transparency, and providing updates on treasury management initiatives. The budget requested is 6,000 $UNI, with an hourly rate of $200 per hour.

The next steps include:
1. RFC (Request for Comments) from March 19 to March 26.
2. A temperature check from March 26 to March 30 to gauge interest in launching the UTWG.
3. If the temperature check passes, a 7-day period will be provided for prospective candidates to apply to the working group on the forum.
4. A Snapshot election will take place from April 7 to April 11, allowing the DAO to vote for the two remaining members of the UTWG.
5. The onchain vote will be live from April 12 to April 19, batching together the formation of the working group, its four members, and sending the budget to a multisig.
6. Over the course of 8 weeks, the UTWG will examine various treasury initiatives for Uniswap DAO and create at least two viable treasury management options, which will be put into their separate RFC/RFP processes. The exact implementation after this step is to be determined based on the working groupâ€™s research and adjacent legal developments.

Title: Technical Support Guild Budget Proposal for Initial Operations

The proposal aims to secure a budget of $66,000 over four months for the Technical Support Guild, focusing on improving documentation, resolving tickets, and streamlining error reporting. The budget will be allocated as follows: $12,000 per month for guild member incentives using Disperse contracts and Coordinape circles, and $4,500 per month for bounties to encourage larger deliverables.

The Technical Support Guild's objectives in 2022 include improving documentation, resolving tickets efficiently, creating a platform for error reporting, decentralizing the guild, and identifying solutions that enhance its decentralization.

Key performance indicators include all tickets being resolved within an average of 1.67 replies per ticket, an average response time of less than 5 hours, and an average resolution time of less than 8 hours. The first month's report shows the guild has successfully taken over HelpScout ticket resolution, with a team of six onboarded members, eight more on the waiting list, and a focus on improving documentation and FAQ.

The distribution for the first month is proposed to be $5,625 among all guild members, with 80% decided by a Coordinape Circle of the guild members. The Technical Support Guild Steward will provide wallet addresses and weighted portions of the distribution to the Executive sub DAO by December 22, 2021, enabling each guild member to receive payment by December 28, 2021.

The text discusses four options for distributing vested Sushi tokens, which were agreed to be vested for 6 months three months ago. The text discusses the vulnerability of Minions, an extension of Moloch DAO, to 51% attacks due to lack of a RageQuit mechanism and proposes a solution: "disputable Minions." This feature would allow minority shareholders to challenge Minion proposals that contradict the DAO's operating agreement or investment mandate. The process involves opening a dispute during a delay window after every executeAction() method is called, with an ADR provider chosen from a hard-coded list and payment made for their services. If the dispute is valid, it blocks the proposal from execution. The text also mentions the team behind this proposal, including burrrata, HeavyChain, and RaidGuild, and provides funding information for the project.

The Real World Finance team discusses MakerDAO as a bank-like entity similar to traditional unregulated banks like Eurodollar banking. The goal for MakerDAO is to have a high lending rate (higher risk) and low funding rate (low perceived risk). However, solvency and liquidity risks exist, which could potentially lead to higher deposit interest rates. Despite these risks, DAI demand remains high due to factors like AMM models and DeFi farming. The long-term strategy is to improve branding, marketing, user experience, integrations, and network effects to stay competitive. USDT's market share decline is an example of this theory in action.

The latest edition of the Collateral Status Index (CSI) is presented, divided into four sections based on the Collateral Onboarding (COB) process:
1. Collateral Application Status - lists all collateral application statuses before prioritization and those removed from the process.
2. Prioritized Collateral - a pool of collateral prioritized for the Assessment step, determined by various factors including MIP6 collateral application completeness, market conditions, and alignment with MakerDAO strategic objectives.
3. Collateral Work In Progress (WIP) - all collateral in the Assessment through Executive Vote execution stages or those failing a Governance Poll or Executive Vote.
4. Active Collateral - all collateral in Business Review status, recently updated ones, and those recently offboarded.

Updates are made by a limited number of collateral stakeholders to ensure data integrity. Any discrepancies should be reported through the #collateral-engineering-services-public channel on the MakerDAO Discord server. Specific collateral questions or comments can be posted in the MakerDAO forum within the collateral application forum post, while general CSI update questions can be posted here.

For more information and data, use the provided links to view raw and filtered data on the CSI spreadsheet. The Collateral Onboarding Framework model is included for historical purposes only.

The RwaUrn contract is designed to manage Dai tokens and allows only the outputConduit address defined by governance during deployment to receive any Dai drawn from the contract. It does not inherit other contracts.

The RwaToken contract is a standard ERC20 token with three state-changing functions: transfer, transferFrom, and approve. The balanceOf(address) of the deployer of the contract is set to 1 WAD at deployment. There are 18 decimals of precision.

The RwaConduit contract has a single function, push(), which can be called by anyone with a current MKR balance and holds transitory funds. However, for centrifuge assets, the centrifuge manager contract acts as a compliant RwaConduit. The technical risk associated with this contract is considered low but there may exist some unknown technical risks in the details of tinlake liquidations.

The ERC20 functions of the RwaToken are implemented to industry standard but do not mitigate the allowance race-condition or use a SafeMath library. The core functions of the contracts are very limited and only governance or trusted addresses can lock, free, draw, or wipe Dai in the RwaUrn.

The text discusses the Internet Computer, an extension of the public internet that functions as a global compute platform, allowing developers to create websites, IT systems, and internet services without relying on server computers or cloud services. It aims to address issues such as system security and monopolization of internet services.

Key features include:
1. Unstoppable tamperproof environment for native software.
2. Simplified interoperability between different systems.
3. Automatic persistence of memory, reducing the need for traditional files and standalone infrastructure like database servers.
4. Support for "autonomous software" that runs without an owner, enabling the creation of open versions of mainstream internet services.
5. Integration with Internet standards such as DNS, serving user experiences directly to Web browsers and smartphones.

The text discusses whether Aragon Court or the Aragon Network can be considered a "rent-seeking" protocol. Rent-seeking refers to an entity seeking added wealth without contributing productivity, often using government policy to advantage themselves over others. The author argues that Aragon Court is not currently a rent-seeking protocol because it provides reciprocal value for the cost paid by consumers, and competition in the digital economy of Ethereum prevents potential rent-seeking behavior due to the lack of scarcity and the ability for anyone to create a competitor. The author also points out that since Ethereum is a global protocol not subject to government control, it cannot use policy to privilege itself over other protocols.

Title: Swidge Core Wrapper Development Milestones

  1. **License** (GPLv3)
  2. **Documentation**
      - Inline documentation of the code
      - Basic tutorial explaining interaction with the wrapper

  3. **Testing Guide**
      - Core functions will be fully covered by unit and e2e tests

  4. **0x Polywrapper**
      - Write graphql schema for protocol actions
         - Check if the channel between Token A and B is enabled
         - Quote if amount X of token A is swappable to token B
         - Compute output amount and address
         - Make transaction
      - Implement graphql schema methods in Rust using Polywrap Http and Ethereum plugin
      - Write unit tests suite for the core behavior
      - Deploy polywrapper to IPFS (1.5 + 4 + 0.3 = 6 story points)

  5. **0x contract facet**
      - Write contract facet for on-chain infrastructure to communicate with protocol contracts
      - Deploy to EVMs (2.5 story points)

  6. **Bridge Polywrapper**
      - Write graphql schema for protocol actions
         - Check if the channel between Token A and B is enabled
         - Quote if amount X of token A is swappable to token B
         - Compute output amount and address
         - Make transaction
      - Implement graphql schema methods in Rust using Polywrap Http and Ethereum plugin
      - Write unit tests suite for the core behavior
      - Deploy polywrapper to IPFS (1.5 + 4 + 0.3 = 6 story points)

  7. **Smart Contract Upgrade** (0.7 story points)

  8. **Total** (16.8 story points)

   **General Ecosystem Fit**
      - Swidge enables developers to use cross-chain liquidity in a safe and abstracted way, with the certainty that every piece of the system is decentralized.
      - The Swidge Protocol provides its Core Wrapper SDK (Swidge SDK) to protocols for B2B integrations, allowing them to interact with all aggregated protocols in a decentral manner as Swidge does not run any centralized backend.

   **Target Audience**
      - The Swidge Protocol is designed for dApp developers who want a simple way to integrate different liquidity protocols from various chains into their dApps.

   **Needs Met**
      - Swidge meets the needs of dApp developers by providing a straightforward method to interact with any protocol across multiple chains in an abstracted manner.

   **Similar Projects**
      - There are several projects aiming to solve interoperability of liquidity protocols across chains, but most rely on centralized logic or encode transactions for on-chain contracts, which can be a single point of failure in a decentralized financial infrastructure. Swidge addresses this issue by giving users ownership of the transaction encoding process and using Polywrap wrappers to hold the logic of the algorithm that checks possible paths and generates calldata required for contracts. This eliminates any centralized points of risk or exploitation.

In summary, the article discusses the potential for a robust crypto financial system by combining three key components: tokenized real-world credit (Bonds), deep and efficient crypto markets for trading and lending, and cryptobanks to provide maturity transformation.

The author argues that stablecoins can serve as the cash equivalent in the crypto banking system, with fiat-backed stablecoins being on-demand liabilities backed by Treasury bills or bank deposits. However, the interest rate given to stablecoin holders will be limited by the t-bill rate.

To address the mismatch between long-term borrowers and short-term lenders, fractional-reserve banking can be introduced through cryptobanks. This allows a small amount of fiat-backed stablecoins to be expanded to a larger amount, providing more liquidity for economic activities.

The article emphasizes that crypto-banking is different from traditional banking, market-based banking, and shadow banking due to its focus on highly liquid assets as a defense against bank runs. The author concludes that while the crypto markets are still developing, we are close to having a robust Crypto Banking System with the integration of tools like Uniswap for lending, Aave as a money market, and cryptobanks like MakerDAO. However, the Bond part is currently missing, but progress is being made with initiatives like Centrifuge for private credit and Backed and MakerDAO's proposal to onboard up to 1 billion $ of short-term bonds.

Venus is updating its liquidation smart-contract interface to align with the changes in Venus V3 tokenomics. The current 10% liquidation incentive will be divided, with half going to liquidators (95% of the liquidated borrow amount) and the other half to Venus treasury (5%). A new Liquidator contract interface will be provided, replacing the old one after a 30-day grace period.

Liquidators will now call Liquidator.liquidateBorrow(...) instead of vToken.liquidateBorrow(...), and for BEP20 borrows, they'll need to approve tokens to the liquidator contract before calling liquidateBorrow. For BNB borrows, liquidators will send the corresponding repayAmount of BNB along with the liquidateBorrow transaction.

Indexers should listen to the new LiquidateBorrowedTokens event instead of the LiquidateBorrow event, as the previous one will still be emitted but with incomplete information. The upgrade will occur in two phases: first, deploying a fully functional version of the Liquidator contract on BSC mainnet; second, disabling the liquidateBorrow function of vBNB and vBep20 by adding a check that ensures msg.sender == comptroller.liquidatorContract().

Note that the address of the liquidator contract may change without prior notice, and it will become available on chain after phase 2 via comptroller.liquidatorContract(). The new liquidator contract code can be found at this link: https://github.com/VenusProtocol/venus-protocol/blob/master/contracts/Liquidator.sol

Title: Extend Safety Module Protection to Aave V2 on Avalanche
